message: Epilepsy is a part of the lives of many people I know. The smiles on their face, their families, the stories they tell, and the signs that they hold are all part of their lives. People with epilepsy are great.
Let's stop Epilepsy before it stops others!!!

I've been living with Epilepsy since the age of three. I was hit by a truck on Maclay st. I flatlined in the Polyclinic hospital. My grandmother prayed at the foot of my bed and I sat up screaming. The Patriot News did a story on it. Calling me a miracle baby. But it's hard to get SSI. I've been denied five times. But I can't continue to work, because employers fire me, as soon as they discover I have epilepsy.

The reality of it is, it does limit you, and this inhibits you as a person growing up with epilepsy. It is a major handicap that many people don't understand because it is not visible. Even if it is controlled with medication it does not matter. Having epilepsy when I was younger, and they didn't know what was wrong with me, it was hell for me as a child growing up. It made my already teased, and bullied, struggle to learn situation so much worse. I made it, but there is some irreversible damage, and problems that I have to overcome everyday. I am happy that they know more about epilepsy nowadays, thanks to groups like this, and medical research. It is better that everyone can get a better chance at the development, of social skills, mental, and emotional skills, and education, that we all deserve.

If things don't work I'll get Vns, he said better for generalized seizures but I have partial complex. So see what future holds. Been whole wk made this time, yeah!

I've had epilepsy sense the Age of 3 I'm now 35. I've moved mountain's, and have done things Drs said I could never do after living through 3 Commas and 1 Stroke I graduated High School, had a live birth my son Dakotah Wheatley will be 10 this Yr , and I thank God for him every day. I'm now in Pre Grand College Studying Family in Human Services with a Major in Psychology I'm yet Pregnant one's again. Never let a Dr play God Through the Yrs as a child I also had to relearn to walk, talk and fiction as what they call a "normal" person btw there really no such thing as normal. I can talk, walk, drive, be a mom. You are the only person that says I can't not anyone else, and no matter how much you're friends,family, other halfs ect want it for you. You have to want it yourself to thrive btw the Commas and Stroke keeped me in it for years anything is possible if I can do it so can you!

Here are my 4 words, Injury, death, rebirth,growth! on 8-28-11 I had an anyuerism and stroke. Many of the things in my life died, career etc. After hospital time I walk out of rehab in only 19 days.  I had my fist seizure months later and was told "post traumatic epilepsy" from the physical damage to my brain. I have had horrible seizure clusters 10-20 in a day. went through the stages of grief, anger by far the worst, still haunts me sometimes but I learned to be a better me. As with any great  thing it is / was a struggle. The harder you try the stronger you become!  I think I am a better man today!  I hope you have a beautiful day for the run!  Lastly VNS Therapy for Epilepsy has been amazing in my case. I am down to a  little seizure that are more nuisance every couple weeks now and again. and a full tonic clonic every couple months. over hard seizing every week, I'll take it!

As a former truck driver,Sleep had to be something you got wether you were ready or not. My technique, Lay or position comfortably, slow and completely breathe in and out fill your lungs. KEEP YOUR RITHEM STEADY and as you pay attention to the pace you will slowly go out.  For me, worked every time, never took more than 5 min.  with the addition of no visual imput! Radio, mp3 ok, NOT TV! visual input charges the brain to much and makes it harder to fall a sleep.  Hope it helps...

My heart goes out to all who suffer from this condition/disorder as my son and husband both had seizures.  I lost my son when he suffered a seizure on Easter Sunday, April 12, 2009 and died of asphyxiation.  My husbands seizures however did not take him from me, he died of brain cancer in the motor cortex as well as other places.  The most important thing i found out regarding epilepsy is that the patients need to be diligent about taking meds and that they need the right doctor with continuity of care.  Over the 40 years of our marriage my husband would decide he didn't need his meds and we would have episodes of status epilepsy.  He did this early in our marriage but go better because I was relentless about making sure he had his meds.  When our loved ones are having seizures we have to be advocates for them both in hospitals and with doctors because they can't speak for themselves.  They need to see doctors who are especially trained in epilepsy.  My husbands seizures were so bad that we finally got him in to see an epileptologist at Duke University and he prescribed medicine for him that I would administer to him if he started having one seizure after another so that we did not have to make a trip to an ER.  Going to ER always made things worse because the doctors would change his meds and it could take months to gain back the ground we had lost.  My son was a different story as he was very noncompliant in taking his meds and he was also bipolar and had hemophilia.  He was his own worst enemy when it came to his conditions but he was a grown man and as a mother there was only so much I could do to help him especially after the government put rules in place that prevented parents from having access to medical information on their children once the reached puberty.  When patients are having seizures they cannot communicate with medical personnel therefore for those of you who have children or a significant other you ned to make sure that someone has healthcare power of attorney in these type situations or your hands are tied. If things are not available in hospitals that are essential for diagnosis and treatment of your loved ones take them to a facility that has the proper equipment.  You loved ones can't fight for themselves so you have to do it for them.  If i can be of assistance for any of you please feel free to contact me.  It took me 40 years to learn what I know about epilepsy and treatment and i am happy to share what I know if it will help even one person or one parent from losing a child as I lost mine.  Praying for all.  May God bless you all.

We lost our son who developed seizures at the age of 40.  Just 3 months short of living with seizures for nine years.   You cannot imagine our grief.  He was being primed for surgery, but died of asphyxiation before that took place.   We will never, ever get over our grief.  Please approve and research medications quickly to save lives.  Rick Muñoz was our son .  48 years old.

I went through every anti-seizure-free medicine; then as every new medicine came out, I also took that too.  Til, I was out of options!  Medicare & Medicaid spent more money on step- protocol, due to trying the medicine's before that did not work before and I changed insurance companies.   Now, I have learned it is too late for brain surgery due to trying now; seizures effect both sides of the brain.   I also had a Sister pass away from her seizures!  How many more are going to DIE BEFORE THE RIGHT STEPS ARE TAKEN!

I was Diagnosed with Epilepsy and Tuberous Sclerosis Complex when I was nine year's old it was a very Difficult time for me and my mom was told I would end up in an Institution or Dead that was thirty year's ago by the Grace of God I'm still here and in good health childhood was very Difficult I thought I was suffering from a Nervous breakdown this girl spread a rumor that I had AIDS and it went through the whole school what ever doesn't kill you makes you stronger still beating the odds through faith GOD and family. :-)

I was misdiagnosed since childhood.  The alienation from my peers due to ignorance and discrimination on the job was horrific.  This was before the government enacted laws preventing this.  I was fired.  My insurance rates were always higher and still are.  Finally in my thirties, we learned it was a benign brain tumor that had been there since birth.  I had the surgery, 3x.  I am off seizure meds.  Seizure free for 30 years, but I have permanent damage from the last second surgery.  I have a tendency to drag my right leg and I can fall a lot.  Also, I have muscle tightness on my entire right side.  I can no longer work a full time job.

A question I have for all of you, what can you do aside from getting another doctor and writing to the medical board with a complaint when the doctor doesn't listen and is causing your son even more seizures? Aldo anyone that is interested in surgery ,you will go threw 6 months of testing.Its not something that is just jumped into! My life just began after my surgery almost 19 years seizure free! Better than ever , I started a rental business went back to college was back to work 6 weeks later.And of course wrote my book and console   People for Brain surgery!

Like everything else we are not the most desirable place to be , so we search for answers and research and diagnostic tests for stability . My daughter has that condition , my aunt had that condition, one Jacksonian, my daughter partial complex, right temporal since age fifteen or earlier? Thanks for sharing , it inspires me to know that there is a voice out there for epilepsy.

in 7th grade I started a new school the teacher called assembly put me at the front and said"the new student has epilepst children that means their heads not right so no loud noises or sudden movements now everybody welcome the new student quietly. I changed schools three months later those three months were hell. many fools did similiar things all throughout my education

It enhanced my depression, finding the right meds became demanding, I had just been promoted when I first started getting them. The meds screwed up my head pretty badly. I had to re-learn how to work in the corporate world. I went from a nearly photographic memory to being unable to remember what was said to my face after I walked away. The stress of changing my life, because it was so much harder, just made everything get worse. I have serious depression as well and the combination has made me a different person. I am angry, I am sad, I am hurt and always feel broken. My seizures are controlled by a nice expensive cocktail of meds, but I eventually have a breakthrough seizure then have to work from there. 
I started making bad choices and feeling like I wasn't myself. It caused me to leave one stressful, but familiar, job for a different stressful job, which I ended up walking out on. I got three more good jobs after that, but was treated differently in every one of them once I had a seizure in the office. I was treated with kid gloves, but in a completely biased way. I was looked over for promotions, I became the black sheep or the problem child. I did work equal to or better than my teammates but it wasn't relevant.
I had friends, and I literally have none. I hurt emotionally and physically every day. I spent five months job searching,  interviewing, writing cover letters and changing my resume and thank you notes only to come up completely dry. My depression is dark and vicious and I have another cocktail of meds for that. Then I take concentration meds because I'm so tired, and I take pain meds because my body hurts every day.
I was fun, funny, athletic, likeable, nice, and good-hearted. Now I'm just not. I used to play volleyball with friends and then at some point I just wasn't on the team anymore. Same with basketball. And happy hours. And sitting with a group of friends with season tickets for football games. And stopped being asked to go to things. Etc.

So other than losing jobs, changing my speech patterns, adding very dark, negative thoughts into my everyday life, gaining 135 lbs, changing how I feel, keeping me in constant vigilance, disrupting the plans of my retired parents, alienating me from friends and colleagues, adding fear to my son and wife if I make a strange noise or breathe funny, feeling judged and discriminated against often, feeling insecure personally, causing me pain, making me a worse person with less ideals and hopes to being judgmental, angry, and mouthy, it hasn't impacted me or my relationships in any way. Aside from those things.
I always get treated differently because I suffer from epilepsy.  :'(

1978 I was diagnosed with epilepsy, I was 14 going on 15 and in 8th grade.  The stigma was so strong people thought back then it was a commencal disease?  I found who were really my friends, and those who were so misinformed from their parents.   Now some 30 years later, there are still people who when I tell them I had epilepsy their attitude changes.

Only if they knew about it.  If I wasn't having a seizure, no one knew.  I remember I got a new boss, he didn't understand epilepsy when I told him I had it and treated me with kid gloves.  He wouldn't let me do anything.  I assured him I would let him know when I was having a seizure.  Fortunately, I had only one in front of him (that was enough)  After that, they finally found the right medications for me to take and my seizures stopped completely. He was still leery though.

My husband's family have completely distanced themselves from him, many of his friends have abandoned him as well.. He says it doesn't bother him.   He says if they can't handle me at my worse then they don't deserve me at my best...I think that says it all!  Definitely puts reality into perspective and you find out who really will be there in the end!

Oh, also, after I was let go from my last position, I was told I was using my epilepsy and depression as an "excuse" for why I "underperformed." I underperformed because I had too much work, and asked numerous times for a transfer to a similar job, or for assistance with the amount of work I had, which was easily quantifiable to be significantly more than my teammates.

I have seen 4 different epileptologists and 3/4 were caring and wonderful. The next 3 were absolutely wonderful. 2 moved away and I have been tight with my current one for about 6 years. I love her to pieces! She is wonderful! She makes sure my bones are solid, checks my kidneys and my liver, discovered my brain tumor, she looks at my total health! She is at henry ford in Detroit!

Thankyou for sharing...my son is a stay at home Dad...my grandaughter has a cell phone and knows what to do if Dad has a seizure...but ppl.judge him not knowing about his condition...he is a great Dad n his wife is a patient hard working lady...hes been having granmal seizures since childhood...its taken a toll on his body...his back has fractures his skull has scars...but the pain thats the worst is the judgement people professionals and even doctors have had its taken a toll on his selfesteem but he is tough and has coped with and learned to accept that society can be cruel and its all because they are ignorant and but for the grace of God they have never had to learn what its like to have epilepsy! I too have a husband with epilepsy. Reading your blog I literally thought I was reading my own story. Many similarities. He has had epilepsy since age 8, worked all his life,  controlled with medication until October of 2013, when he began to have breakthrough seizures and since no medication has worked. Dealt with looks when he seized in public but never a helping hand. Remarks from his coworkers calling him names like retard. Or people refusing to be next to him. He underwent many studies, test etc. To determine where the seizures are coming from. He had surgery in December 2014, new year's Eve..we, I thought finally, a new year a new start for our lives. Didn't work. Still seizing, all grand mal, we don't have any warning of when they will come and like you I deal with his state afterwards. He can't work either. And because of his condition, there are many simple things we take for granted I can't have him do. He is going through occupational, speech and physical therapy once a week. He also has a seizure about once a week. We have a family, three beautiful girls. We are doing and making the best of it all.
My daughter has epilepsy and will never work. She is so drugged she cant stay awake in am. Without it she has more seizures. She has 1-2 a month now. Desparate. God lives her and so do we!

I have had epilepsy for 14 years it is a struggle but this is my life.  I have been seizure free for 2 years.  Hopefully I will stay that way.

I know the feeling i was a cna for 13 years and seizure free for 20 years then i fell and had 3 concushions and my seizures have now returned and cant work and trying to explain that to people and the goverment is hard and when you get looks like well you sstill take care of your child so you can work or get told you can be a waitress when your seizures can happen just talking to someones and drop something and you can look at them and no one can tell you are in one cause it just seems like you are in a daze doesnt help. never knowing when one can happen is the worst feeling in the owrld i am 40 and have lost all but my right take care of my child so far and if i loose that i loose my whole world . i have tried to go to work and i tell them i have a seizure condition and by law they can tell you that they wont hire you because of that but you can tell by their look its why . they just say we shall see what hapens.

I have Epilepsy (clonic/tonic) which I was born with.  They went dormant for 22 years, had three, then went dormant again, in 2012 they came back and now medication does not control them.  I had a VNS put in last year and I still have them but instead of 2-3 every month I have 1-2.  I worked since I was 18 but in 2012 was told by my Epileptologist at Mayo Clinic that I am unable to work due to not knowing when my seizure will hit. The hardest thing is losing my independence.  Not being able to drive or work is hard.  But I stay positive! <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+008A> Prayers for everyone.

The stigma and even judgment from people continues to astound me.  Having gone through breast cancer and the many failed reconstruction surgeries, chemo, septic infections (which is thought is what caused my epilepsy), all of it was easy compared to what has come from having epilepsy.  People treat you like you are crazy, made it up - you name it.  I mentioned in another post, I even had an ER room kick me out, after arriving by ambulance, from a drop seizure that left me unable to walk or control my left side.  But, with it, has come many awakenings.    My politics, my views on law enforcement, pretty much everything changed after one too many abuses - inflicted on me and seeing others (like kids and dogs) go through it.  Mine are not under control either.  Working has gone from professional to little cleaning jobs and stuff (also awakened me to how many of these people are treated).  I have gone through long periods without working, which devastated me and my daughter financially, but kept going.  I'm glad to hear of a supportive spouse and glad I found this site.  After having even my primary care physician treat it like I had lost my mind, I found one of the best neurologist in the country who gets it.  Thanks for sharing your story about stigmas.

I hope my daughter has a spouse that will help her and have this much empathy one day. She is 10 and has had seizures since she was born. Last couple years they have been sparse, but there were years there were many per day. Never know when they will be on the upswing again. It's hard living in so much fear, she is the strong one though. I don't think people realize how hard epilepsy is to live with.
Live with it and then decide it is hard.

I didn't have problems falling asleep. My last job was working at a convenience store and people would call in saying they couldn't work their shift, so being a manager, I'd have to. Working an 8 hour shift on 2-3 hours of sleep would always trigger my seizures. My boss would come in and refused to let me go home as soon as he got to work. Fortunately I found a good doctor who wouldn't stand for it and put me on disability. I haven't worked in over 3 years and was deemed permanently disabled last year because my seizures were so bad.
My doctor told me no caffeine and no lights at night except maybe a very little night light.  It doesn't help.  Still exhausted
It doesn't matter how much I sleep I'm always exhausted.
I'm always tired no matter how much sleep I get
I have these problems.  Im 25 and I have had epilesy since I was 2 years old.  I am now waiting to make an appt at a sleep study.

As a FORMER truck driver I could not always pick my sleep time. This method worked for me then and now.  Take a long deep breath, Let this first lung full of air out at a speed that is twice as long as it took to fill them. breath in deep again and repeat. Change the balance so the inhale is as long as the exhale and truly focus on the rhythm. what ever "crap" you have on your mind will give way to maintaining the equal rhythm, personally I can be asleep in about 5 min tired or not. Your body will seem to sleep what it needs if you are not interrupted by external intrusions. As I have 50yrs old in my sights the "midnight pee" thing gets me but falling back is just that simple
I usually sleep after work and then stay up for a bit and then go back to sleep and I'm 21 and had it since I was 3

I actually wrote a letter to the Fox network after an episode of House.  In one scene the actors were restraining a patient having a seizure.  People who have epilepsy and those around them know not to restrain a person having a seizure.  I thought it was unwise and ill informed and a tiny bit irresponsible for a medical show to show people doing the exact opposite of how a seizure should be handled.
No, since I have only seen grand mal seizures portrayed. All types should be portrayed accurately

It seems like everyone on tv who has seizures has grand mal seizures. It is just for the shock value. I don't really feel it's the best way to do it, though. The average person doesn't know what seizures are like except for what they see on tv. People never know I'm having seizures unless I tell them, or unless they are very familiar with my situation. Except for the obvious grand mal seizure which everyone recognizes. I've been mistaken as drunk, high, and retarded. Once in a HOSPITAL while visiting a friend I had a seizure (grand mal) in a bathroom, and woke up in the PSYCH WARD!!!! They probably found me when I was partly awake and confused. I don't recall it. It just irks me that in a hospital I was misdiagnosed so badly, and I could have needed medical help from a fall in the bathroom with the hard walls and floors.... Obviously, once evaluated they realized I was fine, mentally. Looking back I kind of feel like I should have done something. It was SO wrong!!!

I agree, growing up my parents told me never to let anyone know because they would treat me different. We moved from CA to KY when I was 15 years old. My mother told the school that I had Epilepsy and on the first day of High school I was put in special education. I was actually a very good student and was removed from special ED, but that is the stigma that goes with epilepsy. I am very careful of who I tell about my condition.

I'm a nurse and got moved out of the department I wanted and loved after I had a seizure. They've even gone as far as asking if it's safe for me to work as a nurse. My neurologist has kept close tabs on me and doesn't see an issue as of yet. I'm really considering changing jobs and just not saying anything but then what if i have a seizure? Am I seeing myself up to be fired?
It was extremely hard for me. Unfortunately I do not have a positive story about my epilepsy and workplace experience.

Ppl seem to be okay with it at work. Then I had a seizure while working nights. They let me switch to strictly day shift so I can have a normal sleep schedule. But I know some of my co-workers talk about me for not having to work nights, even though everyone knows I have epilepsy. I'm just used to people talking about me behind my back saying it's a flimsy excuse.

I really must agree.  At my current employer, I let them know in a rather violent way.  I had a seizure.  If I had been a regular status employee, I would have told them long before so that they would not be caught unawares.   Luckily, I had good people around me including a fellow employee who is an EMT.  Other people aren't so lucky and some may have even died.

I have epilepsy since I was 8 yrs.old, and I always told my employers about my condition, they need to know for your safety and for the safety of others. And I always got hired....yes it's a stigma, but I keep my head held up high and never let my condition get me down....
I have had seizures from the time I was little and now im 38. I told employees and employers regarding my condition on case something went horribly wrong.

The brain is a miraculous tool and there are many ways to get around some of our memory difficulties.  As for my biggest difficulty it is my spatial recognition and memory.  Simply put this is remembering where objects are in relation to other objects like remembering land marks, remembering what I see visually.  Fortunately my auditory memory is fairly good so if I talk myself through situations and describe things and situations to myself I am able to compensate for my lack of visual/spatial memory.  The most powerful tool you have as being a person with epilepsy is too learn as much as you can to give you the tools to fight back!

I use to love to read & write poems, & be good at writing & spelling I can't even remember at times how to spell a word or what I'm reading! I'm constantly tired the only support I have is my husband & sometime my son & my daughter, its hard on me so I take it day by day! I know what you all go through its hard not remember things just trying stressing & having seizures!!  My thoughts and prayers go out to you all god bless you all!!

I got diagnosed with epilepsy back in 2008 ever since then I hardly remember anything before that, the last seizures I had were around 17 in a hour, I always have to get reminded by family and friends but they all understand, my memory well get better has time goes, I jus think god for the life, friends an family I have <U+263A>

I had epilepsy seen i was born it is sad but i make it if people  do not understanding  that i feel sad for them . I make it day by day .

Those are two-liners. A bigger thing, anyway, is NOT APOLOGIZING for your epilepsy. It isn't something to be ashamed of.  I'm epileptic and will never apologize for anything involving my seizures. If anything, non-epileptics should apologize to us. I've met so many epileptics who are actually ashamed to the point where they hide it from everyone. That's messed up. If I can't remember a fact, or someone's name, I may certainly will not apologize. Just, "I have epilepsy and that's what seizures do. They damage your brain." usually that prompts a conversation about epilepsy wherein I correct all the stupid things non-epileptics think about epilepsy and seizures. Just stop apologizing and be matter-of -fact.

I've been blessed with two WONDERFUL epileptologists over the past 20 plus years.  Neurologists are good, but their knowledge is much more general, whereas the expertise/focus on epilepsy that an epileptologist has, can make a H U G E difference in the quality of care one receives as far a treatment for epilepsy.  If AT ALL possible, get a referral to an epileptologist, even if getting there is a little inconvenient.

When you find someone that specializes in the issue you cannot control, what a difference. My husband was told by his neurologist that he is medication resistant and there was nothing else he could do. Horrible to hear for someone who has cluster seizures several times month, his epileptoligist has given us options and hope

My neurologist could not effectively treat my epilepsy, and he had the great honesty & humility to advise me to go to an epileptologist. I am eternally grateful to my neuro for that. My epileptologist tried different med combos before moving onto neurosurgery, for LTL re-section. I love my epileptologist!
Our epileptologist was able to achieve seizure control on our 9 year old when our neurologist could not.
My epileptologist understands the disorder so much better than any neurologist I have ever met! There is a HUGE difference, and recommend that all Epileptics go to one for better care.

My son was treated unsuccessfully by a neurologist for many years.  We were told his episodes were psychosomatic.  Once getting to an amazing epileptologist, we were told the EEG which is normal for him is so abnormal for most others that it takes a special talent to decipher his seizures from the other brain waves.  It's been a bit over 20 years that she's worked with him - epilepsy surgery at Mayo and VNS implanted, he's still not totally controlled, but he's light years ahead of where he was.   I *highly* recommend this sub speciality to anyone not finding success through the regular channels.

My original neurologist didn't recommend one to me but when I got fed up with the care I was receiving and decided to change even though I was only looking for a neurologist I ended up finding an amazing epiletologist
I think that after over 35 yrs of neurologists with no real seizure control, it's time to refer myself to a epileptologist.
Such better care from the epileptologist! No ego problem either! Will NEVER go back to a neurologist ever again!
They are wonderful in their field and very hard to find! Mine retired a few years ago and I'm struggling to trust a Neurologist for answers.
If you or a loved one has epilepsy that is not controlled by a pill or two, or if the side effects of your medication is outweighing the good, you must see an epileptologist.

My daughter has always gone to the Cleveland Clinic. I didn't know it was so unknown. She's always had one and I know there are some at UH too in Cleveland. I guess we're lucky to live so close to world class care. Explains why there's always patients from all over the world there when we stay in the pediatric monitoring unit for a video EEG.
Is an epilepsy. Specialist. In epileptic seizures.

Made ALL the difference with my daughter.  They were more focused on what types of seizures,  possible triggers, better knowledge of meds and side effects and even concerned with how meds effect future life events, marriage and family.  Better testing, better results and better communication.  Highly recommend it!  Good luck and prayers for all who deal with epilepsy.  My heart goes out to you.  Smiles

These comments are AWESOME!!! SO, I HAVE to share a mini version of my Eplipsey Saga... I had my first grandma in the shower, while my mom was at work in... A HOSPITAL... the medics wrapped my burned body in a bath towel!!! So, I had to be put in a tub of ice.. Then, grafting surgery.. I was 27!!! Spent the next ten years being called a Retard, freak... Losing job after job.. And.. My Dr's. Spending less than 15mns with me, every six months.. Blaming my onset on my Female hormones... And, doping me up on meds... A client for years, helped get me in for tests at the MAYO... One hour there and meeting my doctor.. He told me I had a brain tumor, non-cancerous and BRAIN SURGERY was the answer... WOW!!! 9 Nerologists, 7 MRI's, and 32 medications... And.. I was probably born with this!!! The MAYO was blown away... I had surgery ten years ago this past week.. And, have only had two seizures in the past ten years... BUT, that label has stuck with me.. Because Now, I have side effects of the chuck of my brain they removed... I was very fortunate... I do my best to go on.. Pay the gift my customer gave me forward... And... Would like to tell the world my story, because of the label, Sigma, etc.. That continues... I was lucky to have met Coach Jerry Kill a year ago (MN golfers coach with Epilepsy) told him he was my Hero... I pray that social media can help prove that those with Seizures & Eplipsey are VERY capable of living life.. Coach Kill is a shinning example (college educated, great coach) and he is working with my local Epilepsy foundation to help pass along this label is unfounded... <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+0082> I was blessed at my Worst... And, I just want to tell the world that to help others that face the challenges of daily life... With this.. Not to be so quick to judge!! Bless you ALL!!! <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B2><U+009F><ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B2><U+009F><ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B2><U+009F>

Hes been with me through both brain surgeries that I've had for my epilepsy.  11/25/1996 I had a partial right temporal lobectomy. Several years ago, when my husband and I were young and best friends, he was dating a young single mom whom he thought he had strong feelings for, and thought those feelings were returned. After several months of dating, they agreed he should move into her place. Everything seemed fine. She knew he had occasional seizures, but had never seen one. Two days after he moved in, he had a grand mal on her floor. She shut her infant child in their room, and scared, continued to let him lay there bleeding, unsure of what to do. She eventually got ready, dropped her child at daycare, headed to work. She told me about the seizure, how she had never seen anything like it and said, "I dont think I can handle this." 
"Do you love him?" 
"Yeah . . . " 
"Then anything is possible."
She went home and he was sleeping, packed up the few things he brought with him, and put them in her trunk. When he woke up, she drove him back to his parents house and broke up with him. He was so sad and heartbroken. She didn't even want to try to help or learn, just gave up on him when the first real relationship obstacle appeared.
My husband knew i had them,but still ask me to marry him, yes 33 years and still kicking with them, yes that is a man that can deal with us with these seizures, over 25 or more years.
I have taken medications close to 60 years now.  I have a wonderful husband, family and friends and live as normal life as I can.   PTL!!!
I had a hard time dating. Since i can't drive no woman wanted me until i found a woman that loves all of me and she accepts all of me

Remind yourself.  There are over a million medical problems. Epilepsy is just one. The majority of people you meet and know may develop a medical problem.  It may be far worse then epilepsy or quite minor.  This is life.  We All have our ups and downs.  Do not let others let you feel down.  Remind yourself- they may just be a bit naive.  Common of many people, until they experience a medical problem or a close relative does.  Try your hardest to remind yourself of all the good things you can do and enjoy. Everyone is special in one way or another.  You are too!!!

My sweetheart came with Epilepsy!  I love him. His seizures while scary are manageable (grand mal). I clear the area of danger, count the minutes, call paramedics after 5 minutes, and follow to hospital,  if necessary. I take him home, tuck him in bed, and wait for him to come back. They are a once in a blue moon and sometimes have humorous effects. One time he spoke in numbers for an hour. Another time he forgot my name and called me Darlin' for 3 months.
Once I learned how to control them my life got much better.

Your doctor has to be your friend or get another one.

Be sure your Dr. has YOUR best interest at heart, and not just his/her's (basically, all they want to do is CYA). Had same neurologist for 20 years (not by choice, parents picked him out when I was still child). Kept him until my 30's, when his 'expertise' almost killed me with Steven Johnson's syndrome, told me I should never have children b/c if I ever get divorced no one would give me custody of my child (WTF?!), and told me he couldn't cure me, just help 'control' seizures (which his answer was to overmedicate me). Do NOT be afraid to question their actions or suggestions, based on your needs and lifestyle. And when they decide it's ok for you to wait 2 hours AFTER your scheduled appt (that you had to leave work for b/c unlike a neurologist, you aren't a millionaire) that you had to catch a ride too as well b/c you can't drive, then its time to say you and your time are worth more to someone who cares..... 4 years, seizure free all b/c of a NEW dr. that found out more about me in 2 week hospital stay than previous dr. did in 20 years.

Your Doctor should be your friend is right.  I had one.  She went to another state.  She was good.  I felt that I could tell her anything, like Family.  I was so very comfortable with her.  It really is important to have that good doctor friend patient relationship.
I LOVE my gastro doctor! (My Nuerologist, not so much) He goes above and beyond his job. Always taking time to listen.no matter how busy he is!

I'm straight forward with my PCP & Nuerologist. They have been professional & bluntly honest with me, since my 1st seizure in 1999. Though i moved upstate NY, i always go to NYC, to see them & I'll keep them, as long as I can.

It was bad when I was younger. I would have daily grand mal seizures. Sometime as many as 8 in one day. Now I only have partial-complex seizures and only about 10-15 a month. I've had 4 jobs and have been laid off 3 times because of just 1 seizure. Now I'm just trying to start my own epilepsy awareness company with my best friend who also has seizures. When I have a seizure, I'm confused and can't remember words or how to talk. I've had right temporal lobectomy surgery when I was 13 and I'm now on my 3rd V.N.S. When I had brain surgery, when I woke up from it, I didn't know anything, anyone, who I was, I didn't know a word of english, I didn't even know how to move my arms and legs. Luckily over the years much has come back to my memory but not all of it. I have forgot many things like I did in my past. Especially the good things. I went through high school only knowing the words yes and no. While having on average 3-5 grand mals a week. I would wake up with pee and sometimes poop all over me in the middle of the hallways. Everyone would be laughing and pointing fingers at me. Now its funny too me but back then it was 24 hour stress. Panic attacks and much more.
Mine is horrible!!  Sometimes my words run into each other , I can't recall certain past events with family and that makes me feel like I wasn't even there!!

Pay right temporal lobectomy I couldn't remember what happened,  was said, what I saw 2 minutes ago.   Tomorrow will be 7 years since the surgery and I have learned that though my memory doesn't always work I can work with my memory.  Routine is important,  the more practice in routine you are the less things you have to consciously remember daily.  Then,  find the tools that work for you, whether written or electronic, and use them regularly.  Lastly, ask for help from others as you learn to compensate for what was lost.
I understand because my memory has been so affected I felt I had the start of alzheimers,,my Dr gave me a test to prove to me I wasn't

My daughter, age 13 has epilepsy. We have to try our best to keep her routine the same everyday because the littlest change could cause emotional breakdowns. Her school has been wonderful about notifying me of upcoming tests and projects because she will forget the dates and will think it's the next day instead of a few days away. We try and be supportive of her at all times because we love her and want her to be happy. I wish all of you happiness, love, and the support you deserve.

I struggle daily with short term memory loss.  The only way I get thru it at work is to constantly keep a notebook of what I do thru out the day. It helps so much. Now if I can get in that same routine at home. :-)  but I do have the post it's hanging, and notes written here and there. And always putting things in their special so I know where there are when I need them. If I don't keep a routine, or if it's not routine, I will not remember. It stinks having memory issues.
GOD BLESS YOU ALL!!!

I Found Out that they're Certain Medications Out there; whether they're Old/New That could help w/the Memory Recovery. It just depends upon What Type of Seizures y'all have: & Which Rx's will work for y'all. We've all got 1 thing in common; that's the Seizures. We all need to learn to listen to Our Bodies. If you're Lucky enough to have warnings; then notice, when and/or where: they happen. Read your Rx Labels, and find out which One's Affect you. Then Explain to your Doctor, how Those Medications are Affecting y'all. Tell your Doctor's y'all want Medications w/ 1 Side Affect but without another. That's how you'll find out which Medications will work for y'all. Whenever y'all are put on a New Medication; If those New Medications have a Negative Effect Then Tell them that 1 Medication is Counteracting 1 or the Other Medications; then They'll be able to Find Out Which One's they are. Some Of Our can be Controlled w/Work, & Other's Controlled by Certain Temperature Ranges. Your Prescription Vials/Labels will say which Medications can handle what kind of temperatures they can Handle. So if y'all live in an Environment where it's Warmer than Cold: Then you'll want a Rx that will  keep you from Sweating to Death; or If you Live in a Colder Climate; Than you'll want an Rx that will keep you from Freezing to Death.

No I couldn't live with myself,  so although inconvenient it's best not to drive for me.  I haven't had a seizure since December of last year !

I'm starting to learn now at age 22. I'm not cleared to drive yet by my doctor, long story short.. this doctor has no clue what he's doing so I have to find a new one. Anyway, I have to learn since my husband will be deploying soon and I have to be on my own. I've had control over my seizures and can tell when I'm about to have one. If anything happens I'll just pull over and wait for it to pass.  I'm proud I'm learning so I won't have to rely on others.

My husband could feel his seizures coming on as well. He was a young father trying to support his family. Then one day he had his first tonic clonic, behind the wheel. He made it about 3 miles down the road seizing, hit two cars and a semi  truck, then dead centered a tree 2 inches from a gas line. Thank God nobody was seriously injured, but that was his last day of driving and working. I know its hard at 27 to lose that kind of independence, but we have tho think of how many people he could have killed, including himself. The paramedics said they would not have expected anyone to live after seeing his truck. So I believe if you have a history of seizures, even though they are "controlled" absolutely no driving.
As long as I keep my stress level down and take my meds yes I can drive
Just heal people with epilepsy in Jesus name.

I had my first seizure at the age of 12. The after math was an intense headache the lasted 3 days with me me being sick to stomach to point of dry heaving.It being the mid fifties they put in hospital. They kept me medicated,for 3days we're going to do spinal tap when I woke up. They had know idea what had happened.this went on for another 12 yrs. A neurologist had me take a true and false test of 500 questions. This test kick out the answers that were similar and they were able to diagnose Petite mall Psycho Motor Epilepsy. You can't see me have a seizure, the headache after is my only clue. I have been on meds since I was 24. Now at 66, I have had a stroke, so seizures are mini strokes. Some days you just can't win for losing. That's my story, hope it helps someone.

When I was little my friends didn't like my Mim not allowing me to twirl, spin, climb trees, ride skateboards, etc, etc. She was very ovetprotective because as a child they manifested as dizzy spells. I am not an epileptic, but had a seizure disorder from a scar on the right side of the brain causing occasional seizures. I still take  medication, but it has now been 35 years since I even had a hint of trouble. I ccan sympathize with those who do have epilepsy. I have been blessed with no more problems and when I had them I did not go through near what others do. Take your medicine as directed. Don't skip it because you are feeling well and think you can go without it. Get plenty of sleep, dont spend a lot of time using a computer as watching the screen change with each click can trigger an episode as I am told. Never tthink you are less than anyone else. You are just as good as anyone. People have problems and this is something you cannot help, and it is certainly nothing to be ashamed of. Hold your head high, trust in God, and take care of yourself. When I did have seizures I found out that people were more compassionate than I thought and were willing to do whatever they could to help
I looked for something like this when I went to college. I couldn't find anything. It was 06/07 that I started. More publicity please.

I have epilepsy for years, I have positional tremors and more so on my head.  Last year I started to go to a Tai Chi class for health in a Senior Center.  With tremors and all I decided to take the certification class when it came up.  I passed despite the fear that I may look silly with my head bobbing.  I am still in class and still feel that I will overcome this somehow.  I feel being positive and knowing that I CAN helps me.  I play games on the computer, cross word puzzles just to keep my mind working.  Good luck to you all!  :-)

I was scared and wished I had friends then. That's why today when I see someone with this disability I listen and offer my attention in every way. I let them know I know what their going thru. Working at a hospital I will go and talk to them on my break sometimes. They always say,"thank you" for listening.

I had a license but no longer you must think about other people who could get hurt or killed its just to much to handle. I dont know how id live if i  was responible for hurting someone couldnt live with that happy not driving im58

Where I reside the transportation system is terrible esp. if you commute to another city. You pretty much have to quit your job or take a medical leave, or go on Disability if you lose your license. If you support yourself and reside in an area that family do not reside in, you don't just find travelling to work or to the grocery stores, etc. doesn't make getting around "just a little more difficult", it makes it impossible. That's why so many people have a seizure and will not be open to tell their health care provider as they don't want to be reported to the MOT or DMV. It's can be totally life changing for the worse. I don't blame those who do not report their seizures to their doctor, esp. when they will lose their source of income, job, independence, etc. etc.

ya it is very difficult

Public transit in my area sucks, (MBTA) but I have no choice but to use it. I can't afford a car of any kind and I can't afford to get a permit either. I just made the 8 month seizure free mark for MA this month too. Hopefully someday.

I see comments here about not driving. using public transit, depending on friends etc. I saw one that suggest receiving disability as an option. I have no public transit available to me, my friends all have lives of their own and cannot be my personal chauffeurs, I have applied for disability and was turned down because I am otherwise physically able to work and inability to drive is not a valid reason to receive disability. What I see here are people who are afraid to live and choose to use their epilepsy as an excuse to not do so. People who are not epileptic have vehicle accidents every day and it is usually due to carelessness. Risks are a natural part of life and driving a vehicle for anyone is a risky thing. Yes you should take precautions to avoid the possible negative effects of risky behavior, but taking risks in life are necessary, if you avoid taking risks, you fail to live life to it's fullest. If you marry some one, you take the risk that that marriage might fail, but you will never know unless you take the risk, come what may. Use as much caution as possible, but take the risk and get out and live.
I lost my license for 6 months due to a seizure it sucked but luckly got it back
Very good information
I don't have a driver license, but my friend has one. She has the same thing to.

After my gym teacher in HS was cleared to drive after being seizure free for 5 yrs he went for a drive and had 3 friends in the car with him on the parkway. He had a seizure. No survivors. I was 16yrs old just officially diagnosed finally with epilepsy and had a driver's permit. After that incident I went home, parked the driver's permit in the draw and I'm 50yrs old now and still don't drive. I have a full life, seizure more or less controlled I am allowed to get a license if I so choose. But I'll be damned if I'll be responsible for putting other people's live's at risk because I am so very much in need of an independence I can achieve in other ways. It just isn't worth it. I'm a successful teacher, sole support in my household, use public transportation, and friends, family...and I do not drive.

I only have simple partials, auras during the day and complex partials at night. I'm in my 50's and have never had a seizure while I've been driving. The head of the epilepsy monitoring unit at the University of Pennsylvania fought the DMV to get my license back!!!  I promised the DMV I would not drive while I'm sleeping.
Every time i even think of trying to get my license, i start having seizures more often. Which tells me, i don't need them.

I just happened on to this site,  and I too have controlled epilepsy  caused by a brain aneurysmn that leaked , resulting in brain surgery which left me with scar tissue. My peeve is not being able to receive an implant to control the seizures or at least combine the two, thereby resulting in less need for the medication and it's unwanted side effects, such as liver damage. I am currently having memory issues, where i also have had to give up career choice because of it. Comforting to hear im not the only one.

Had to also give up nursing career and have to take 3 seizure meds which causes memory loss.  I was born with epilepsy but my 1st seizure didn't start til I was 23.  Now I'm 33 and have a nursing license that I can't use.  Was fired on multiple occasion because I am a liability in their eyes.

I also have lost several great careers due to epilepsy. I have memory, speech, and language issues. No one wants to retrain anyone over and over. I go through times where I do not remember my name or how to spell my husbands. After a seizure I don't always know who family members are. It seem that sometimes the medications we take for this make the memory issues worse.  It is scary. 
Thank you for sharing. It is helpful to know I am not alone.
I have 2 Degrees one in A.S. Computer Network and Security Management, and one in A.S. Medical Assistant. I am not able to use either due to the obvious hazards in each field.

Awilda Coll, I know what you are saying. I understand. There are things about my son's childhood that I can't remember. I see pictures and will ask when did that happen? Or family will talk of evens and I can't bring it to mind. It it frustrating.

I also was a nurse for 20 plus years started having trouble remembering why I was doing for that Dr. That's when I was do with complex partial epilepsy couldn't drive an had to quite work because I could become dangerous.  I cried for years over losing my job I wanted to be a nurse since I was a child. Then within a few months my whole world stopped an started in a new direction I was unsure of. My family is awsome I've not worked in 10 years now an I still become sad about not getting to nurse I loved it so much but God has me by the hand an we will win in the end God bless you all
Good for you, Debbie!! Right On!

Hi Ivonne, i began having memory loss after my third seizure. I went back to work realizing i had no  idea what to do. People stared at me in disbelief, and this is probably the most frustrating part. I used to be a 4.0 student. I tried going back to college and failed misserably! I couldnt pass any test. I get frequent migraines, my vision isnt the same so it makes them worse, i cant concentrate, and the memory loss is no help at all. Is your son having issues in school? Maybe you should consider it as a sign. If not sit down and talk to him. I think it's  great that you follow this page, and trying to learn more. It is very difficult  to have to accept that this is our life. The headaches, losing  careers, and not remembering the most important event in our lives. It is always appreciated to have someone who cares and understands. Goodluck to u Ivonne.
Long Term and Short Term Memory issues have made life very frustrating. Thank Father God and Mother God for the Social Security Disability Act, or my family would not have housing, food, etc...

I have memory loss also, was fired from one job, & had to leave one to have brainsugery.  My memory is gone out the window, but the main side effect I have is speech. Just about every time I talk, I have 99.99 percent of people lookin at me with that confused look on their faces, or they come right out & tell me they don't understand what I'm saying, not my friends, just people who don't know me. Yes, for "2days & 2hrs" it hurt my feelings to hear that, but I'm not letting that bother me anymore. I knew I did the right thing, & I'm VERY glad I did. I would rather have lack of memory & speech problem, than having petit mal seizures "every 2mins& 2 secs!!

My oldest daughter is in the same situation,fired from a job of almost seven years,she lost all her benefits after another year on leave. Then the doctors,after 72 hour EEG in hospital stay,inwhich she did not have a single seizure,lol,go figure. The long term insurance company which was paying her long term leave pay cut her checks off immediately. Reason was the doctors found nothing wrong during her stay. She has little seizure meds left,and we cannot afford almost a $1,000.00 a month. This just causes more stress and ofcource more seizures. Without some kind of help from somewhere,her condition is only worsening. She was getting scheduled by her primary doctor to go to the Mayo Clinic,but with no insurance and no income things are not looking to good. She has multiple seizures back to back,and it's not good. Since January 1st,she has had episodes daily,but in that time she has had 5 days that she was seizure free,a Blessing. I have been writing done her episodes on paper,but who in the long pays for her condition is her. She has been having seizures since age 12,the last 2 years have been ridiculous. I pray for her all the time. Her 9 year old son has seen it all,and it scares him to death every time,ad it does me. Thank you for letting me vent a little. May God bless us all

I had seizures in 2010 and life has not been the same since. I have segments of long term memory that seem to be missing. I also have trouble with organizing my thoughts and remembering tasks.I am on meds for epilepsy

I have memory problems. I have been having seizures for 15 years. Sometimes I don't know my name or how to spell my husbands name. I am lucky to have a good support system. I have had seizures in public and that can be really embarrassing. I have learned that the people don't forget but aren't rude. They will ask how I am or just say hi. I have been blessed to live where there are kind people. I read a comment someone said they had a hole new meaning to short term memory, I understand that and can add new meaning to long term memory. Things we learned as young people, every day things, I sometimes can't remember. It is frustrating that I cannot work. However, I put my self in the shoes of an employer, and I know that it would be impossible to retrain someone again and again. 
I am greatful to epilepsy advocates lto be able to share with people who live life with a similar understanding. Thank you all for sharing.
I feel you! "Short-term memory" has a whole new meaning now! It is not a joke!!!

I always walked with my head down, and living in a busy city (L.A.) is scary because I never knew what would happen if I had a seizure (rape, arrested, or run out in the street and get hit by a car. My auras terrified me and the thought/fear of having a seizure scared the living ----out of me.  I never left the house by myself

Yes, it is very embarrassing and strange and frustrating.  I've learned to make little eye contact with people on the street and in establishments, etc., as I so oftentimes do not remember them, but they remember me.  I've learned as well, especially now living in a very small town, not to engage in very many stories or day-to-day experiences, as I have had people say that I told them that before.  It's usually little things, like a cute story of a local dog, etc., but I just don't do it.  All the same, I guess without asking for it, because I do police accountability with regards to abuse to the disabled, the elderly, children, and dogs, they more and more know who I am anyway.  As my work grows, but my memory flails, I guess my message is delivered and brings attention all the same.  I just wish the attention never feel on me.  It does all the same.

Thank you for sharing, Mike. I also experienced viral encephalitis, which left me in a coma for two and a half weeks. When I awoke from the coma and since then, I've had auditory agnosia, memory loss, and epilepsy (which I was only recently diagnosed with.) For years, I lived in constant fear and anxiety. I still struggle every day with some of my disabilities, but I'm so thankful that they've also opened me up to so many opportunities and blessings that I never would have dreamed of before. Your story really touched me. I'm so thankful that I'm not alone in these struggles. I'll be praying for you and all those who struggle with epilepsy and the trials that come along with it. Love to you all

I feel like getting a second one. I want the sign of epilepsy. The purple symbol. Because in May I'll be seizure free for 3 years. That can be my success on what kept my seizures undercotrol. Blessed with my family and friends who's been on my side for 17 years.
I have epilepsy.  No I hate telling anyone they look at me like im a freak..

My son gave me a stuffed frog when he was 4, "to help me feel better". This frog went everywhere through this journey, even into the operating room when I had brain surgery. When I was in the hospital having more testing, I gave Froggy to a poor little girl having the wires put on her head for an EEG, hoping it would "help her feel better". So my first awareness tattoo is so that "Froggy" is still with me. He is on my forearm peeking over the purple Epilepsy ribbon, above my medic-alert bracelet. My second is on my calf, and the Epilpsey "E" always is questioned.  It is a cross with Serenity in the " ---- " and the points have accept, courage, wisdom. In the bottom of the cross is the epilepsy E in red. I wish I could get my computer to post these!

I am so proud to know the people that I've met who have epilepsy. I'll always remember the person holding the sign during the Epilepsy Walk in Washington D,C. that read, "Epilepsy Doesn't Have Me". It's true in Justin's case.

I am 14 and was diagnosed at the age of 7. I had my first grand mall when I was 8 on Feb 3 2008. Afterwards they grew more constantly and I would have them more. I now have light aura's aka ocular epileptic migraines. But I have had this stuffed bear that was given to me by one of the nicest nurses at CHOP in 08. I will never forget that day and I still have the bear. I also hate when people make fun of epilepsy. How would you like it if you were mentally ill or autistic? Huh? People need to think before doing and saying. We all look normal outside but on the inside we are all different.
I tell people often that I have epilepsy, and share it on Facebook.  I like being able to help with some people's misconceptions.  I do NOT share it when applying for a job.
I too have epilepsy! Started having seizures when I was 71years old.Am 73 now. Have had them under control for almost a year now. Dr's have not been able to determine what caused them!

I am just now finding out that I am not alone.  Except for my neurologist, even my family doctor when I was diagnosed in 2008 thought epilepsy was a mental disorder and required a shrink - that's it.   When I had my first seizure, I was in the middle of breast cancer surgery/treatment complications (double masect, failed reconstructions, septic infections- - which is probably what caused the epilepsy), but all of that pales in comparison to the experience of the epilepsy diagnosis.  I could not remember where I lived, where I worked, thought my daughter was 9 when she was 11, didn't remember that our dog had passed away (2 years prior), etc. Could only remember a select few people.   What has happened since then, and my evolvement and enlightenment is still unfolding.

I have more than one type of seizure.  I have simple partial seizures, complex partial seizures, petite mal seizures, and grand mal seizure.  They did not start until I was 18 yrs old.  I had been having déjà vu for as long as I can remember, but thought everyone had that.  One night I woke up in a complex type seizure.  My parents took me to the hospital where I had a grand mal seizure.  It took a month or more to mentally get back to normal.  No doctor has ever been successful at controlling mine.  Most months if I am going to have one, it will happen two weeks prior to my menstrual cycle begins.  I had a simple partial seizure two days ago right after exercising.  My memory is effected by my seizure.  Sometimes it takes days to be back to normal and sometimes it only hours.  I am a teacher with a Masters Degree in School Counseling.  It is by God's grace that I have mentally been able to accomplish what I have.  The seizures are very frustrating for me.  I do not like not being able to remember things.  No one seems to understand.  I have to work EXTRA hard to compensate for it.  I just take it a day at a time.  That is all I can do.

Simple partials would just be an aura. For me it was a rising epigastric sensation--kind of like going down hill on a roller coaster-- and a sudden feeling of doom. I would also instantly become hyper - aware of my surroundings. All of this in just a few seconds. During a complex partial, I would have the aura and I would sense a need to escape. I would then usually try to escape whatever situation I was in. I wouldn't remember anything past the aura. I once tried to get out of a moving car.

Sometimes when I walk I just stop walking and want to talk and know what I want to say but can't move or talk, it's very frustrating....our I don't know I have one at all until the very end I feel my sell come out of it like aura people talk about our someone tells me I had one

I must confess, even after two accidents, it took a threat from a neurologist to turn me in the the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) if I didn't surrender my license, in order to get me to stop driving.  Thankfully, my first accident only involved me and my car.  I actually injured - thank the Lord not seriously - a person in the second accident, went for several years without driving, then started back up again.  At a regularly scheduled appointment, the neurologist saw me dig my car keys out of my pocket as I was leaving his office.  He gave me until the end of the next business day, to turn my license in to the DMV, or he would report me - and he made good on that promise.  I was FURIOUS at the time, but have been thankful ever since.  My son is a fire fighter/paramedic, and has told me some real horror stories of accidents he's seen that were caused by people with epilepsy, in which they or someone they hit was seriously injured or killed, because the patient, whose seizures weren't 100% controlled, continued to drive either without a license, or they had never told anyone they had epilepsy, and still had their license.   With help from family, friends, and the local bus, I can get anywhere I need to go.  It's just not worth the risk.  Even as a bus passenger one time, I got off the bus just as one of my complex-partial seizures began.  The next thing I knew - which could have been anywhere from seconds to a couple of minutes - I was standing out in the middle of a six lane major boulevard, horns honking, people yelling, vehicles screeching to a halt, as I stood in the middle of the intersection. I kept my guardian angels busy that day.

And people wonder why I never got my license. My seizures aren't always predictable, so for everyone else's safety, I decided to rely on family, friends, public transportation, and my own 2 feet to get where I need to go.

I had a grand mal seizure while driving with my two young daughters in the car. I usually have auras, but not this time. They said I drove through a fence and almost hit a house. While I was still seizing, my foot was still on the gas pedal, causing the engine to rev and smoke everywhere. My girls' apparently were beyond frightened!!  I thank God no one was seriously injured, but I have not driven since that day 4 years ago. It has completely inconvenienced my life...terribly!!! :( But, my girls' beg me to never drive again and the thought is frightening. :( I am still not stable. Why would I put the lives of those I love and others at risk?? :(
I had an accident 8 years ago while I had a complex partial seizure.  Went in between two cars and landed one he roof of my car.  Not hurt.  Would like to, but probably won't drive ever again.

I stopped driving several years ago after a man with epilepsy had a seizure and drove through a school and killed a 8 year old girl, I said to myself how would you feel if you did that, you just never know.

I am unable to drive due to Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. I try to walk (very healthy!) every where I can and only use Medical Transportation (bus and cab cost builds quickly) when absolutely needed.Unfortunately (in NYS) epilepsy is seen as a bit of a joke when it comes to these services. This makes no sense as the effort to avoid self-driving is not really for myself but for others :(

I rolled my car at 120mph in rush hour traffic. I've had 30 operations on my leg and will eventually be an amputee due to my injuries. Don't fool yourself if you think, "I can just pull over." I thought that, too. I had auras. Unfortunately, the last thought in the aura was "get to school safely." To an epileptic- that meant drive fast and a straight line there. I wish I would've never driven with epilepsy.

Early in my epilepsy diagnosis I was non-compliant with my meds, and I ran my car under a parked 18-wheel rig. It took the whole roof off my car. If I hadn't fallen sideways I would've been decapitated. I waited the 6 months required by my state, and then with drs permission, began driving. Have been seizure free for 12 years with medication, so now drive regularly. Be compliant. Be wise. Be safe.

After my 3rd car wreck I said thats it, first one my daughter was with me in the car, 2nd my husband who tried to keep us from going off the road but it didn't work and the 3rd I ran through the light and hit some one head on, thank God she saw me coming at he and was able to move some and no one was hurt just messed up cars, another reason to stop driving.  I decided I would need to be at least a year seizure free before I could drive again..that may never happen but me not driving is safe for others also, as well as myself.

The Epilepsy Advocate Facebook page wants to make sure we direct our community to supportive resources. If you or someone you know is in crisis or emotional distress, please call the Lifeline Network at 1-800-273-TALK (8255). When you dial 1-800-273-TALK, you are calling the crisis center in the Lifeline Network closest to your location. To find out what center is closest to you, search the Crisis Center Locator at www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/CrisisCenters/Locator.aspx. If you need immediate assistance, please dial 911.

Just A Dog ?

For all of my animal lover friends....

From time to time, people tell me, "lighten up, it’s just a dog," or, "that’s a lot of money for "just a dog".

They don’t understand all the generous people involved,  the distance traveled, the time spent, the hours of training.  Or the costs involved for "just a dog".

Tim, you are stupid for paying that much money for "just a dog". As Garth saves my life the first week I had "just a dog".

Some of my proudest moments have come about with "just a dog".After all of you made it possible for me to have" just a dog "and all he has done for me I figured it was time to give back, if "just a dog" could bring me so much happiness then why not spread the love! So we visit the Children's hospital and visit with otherwise lonely sienor citizens.  It just makes me happy to see a sick child or lonely sienor get the same joy that I get from "just a dog"! 

Many hours have passed and my only company was "just a dog," because I can now be left alone again so my fiance can work, and have her independence back!  But I did not once feel slighted or afraid being left alone with "just a dog".

Some of my saddest moments have been brought about by "just a dog," and in those days of darkness, the gentle touch of "just a dog" gave me comfort and reason to overcome the day.Or waking up in the ICU units with "just a dog" between my legs quiet and waiting only to check on me! "Just a dog" has never complained, a true loyalty I cannot explain! 

If you, too, think it’s "just a dog," then you will probably understand phrases like "just a friend," "just a sunrise," or "just a promise".

"Just a dog" brings into my life the very essence of friendship, trust, and pure unbridled joy. And now independence and Garth <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B0><U+0095> makes it possible to do things that you all take for granted like driving and feeling safe alone, knowing Garth <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B0><U+0095> will alert or call help if I seize.

"Just a dog" brings out the compassion and patience that make me a better person.

Because of "just a dog", I will rise early, take long walks and look longingly to the future. Now I can go anywhere with "just a dog" and am comfortable that when the time arises, "just a dog" will do what all those hours of training taught "just a dog" to do!

So for me and folks like me, it’s not "just a dog" but an embodiment of all the hopes and dreams of the future, the fond memories of the past, and the pure joy of the moment.

"Just a dog" brings out what’s good in me and diverts my thoughts away from myself and the worries of the day.

I hope that someday they can understand that it’s not "just a dog", but the thing that gives me humanity, independence and keeps me from being "just a man".

So the next time you hear the phrase "just a dog" just smile... because they "just don’t understand
  Right Garth <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B0><U+0095>

Faith and listening to God led me to a great place. I have Epilepsy but the seizures were mostly at night, light ones. The next day I would have terrible Migraine headache and light seizures.  I was given all different medication, nothing worked. Until I was on a plane home, and happen to be seated next to a top Neurologist that had a new medication, that was just right for me? My Neurologist allowed me to take it. It was and has been great. The most important thing I have listened to God's word for me, is to eat well. I ate peanut butter every night. I found foods that I am allergic to THAT being one. It closed my throat,  and caused many of the problems. Another is anti- fungal diet and medication. No white bread, yeast or sugar. This was a cause of low blood sugar. That is a main cause of MY EPILEPSY. I still take medication and always will. Finding a better way to eat, and let God bring you through this,  is the Way. :) I too was in an accident due to not eating. It was the cause of me fainting,  then having a light seizure.I  Never go with my almonds... :) I haven had a seizure in a very very long time.

I worked for a Community Health Center for 7 years. In those years I have never had a write up or received any disciplinary action. On February 16, 2014 my 13 year old son unexpectedly fell to the ground and proceeded to go into a gran mal seizure. I literally lost my mind! I did not know what happened or what was happening. I called the police, paramedics, and then my former boss. They cared nothing about my son. When I returned to work the next week they fired me and told me to wait after hours to collect my belongings because "they did not want anyone to get upset" about my departure. I called and wrote the EEOC and they did nothing. Maybe contacting the EEOC may work for someone else because they sure don't count epilepsy as a concern.

Yes and no. Growing up in the 70's put a huge wedge. My "fits" were an embarrassment in the family, and at that time, I only had petimals. When I started having grandmal seizures in 2002, my married family is very carrying and doing everything they can to help. My friends as well. Great group system. 
Yes, my husband is an over worrier too. It's good and it's bad, but it makes me realize he cares that much about me. He's not doing it because he's embarrassed, but because he's concerned. Been seizure free with medication for 9 years, but we are constantly worried if I will develop a  resistance to my medication,  like I've already had happen. He's someone I can bounce my concerns off of or if I'm feeling something has changed (like memory concerns), I know he's watching out for me.
Learning to let go and let him help me has made us stronger. It's the perspective that makes it positive or negative. I was devastated. My husband helped me learn to see the positive.

I don't think being epileptic has anything to do with affecting your marriage or family because no matter what you are loved. IT's the MEDICINE that takes a toll on a marriage. Spouses have to understand we have no control over side effects, which at times causes friction.  Thank you Gerardo Molina for being a patient, loving, caring and understanding husband.

Not being able to drive really made me lose a lot of self esteem when i was first diagnosed. I lost all of my independence and began having to rely on others to help me get around. May 2015 will be one year since i have suffered a grand mal seizure. I began seeing a new neurologist a few weeks ago to hopefully be able to start driving again. All i have been dealing with is some sleep issues (sleep walking mainly) since my one yr old son was born. This neurologist ordered an eeg and a sleep study for me. I did my eeg last week and to my surprise, it came back very abnormal. My doctor told me i am suffering from silent seizures and have at least ten or more an hour. This was a huge slap in the face. All this time when i thought i was getting better, i have actually been getting worse. Who knows when i will ever be able to drive or if i will ever be able to drive again. I am just ready to have my life back and be able to take my kids anywhere they need to go without having to make sure it doesnt interfere with anyone elses schedule. It just seems so unfair. Im staying positive as best i can and am searching for an online support group. I refuse to let this illness slip me into a deep depression as it has done in the past. If anyone has any advice for me to point me in the direction of others who also deal with this, it would be greatly appreciated. My doctor increased and added more meds to stabilize the seizures but its up to me of course to not allow this to affect me emotionally. I am just ready to have my life back 100 percent. I want it for my children more than anything.

A simple partial seizure that only affects your senses is called an aura. 

AURAS

The part of your brain where your seizures originate (your seizure focal point) also may be linked to a specific type of aura because an aura represents the beginning of a seizure. Since different parts of the brain are responsible for different things, the warning signs you experience will be related to the functions of the section of brain where the seizure is about to occur. People whose seizures begin in the temporal lobe tend to have certain types of auras and those whose seizures begin somewhere else often will have different types. 

Here are some types of auras that can happen alone or in combinations…

Visual changes

Kaleidoscope effects, Visual hallucinations, Shimmering sensations, Vibrating visual field, Distortions in size, shape or distance of objects, Bright lights or blobs, Zigzag lines, Tunnel vision, Blind or dark spots in the field of vision, Curtain-like effect over one eye, Blindness in one eye, Motionless stare, Dilated pupils,

Auditory changes

Hallucinations — hearing voices or sounds that don’t exist, Being unable to understand spoken words, Muffled sounds, Buzzing noises, Loud or whispered volume, Temporary deafness

Physical changes

Weakness, unsteadiness, Changes in heart rate, Sweating, Nausea, Vertigo, Saliva collecting in mouth, Lip smacking, Chewing, Swallowing, Strange smells, Problems speaking, Repetitive movements, Limbs jerking involuntarily, Numbness or tingling on one side of face or body, Feeling of being separated from your body, Needing to urinate

Psychological changes

Confusion, Anxiety or fear, Physical detachment, Déjà vu or Jamais vu, a sense of familiarity or unfamiliarity

My son is 8, he was just recently diagnosed with complex partial seizers. We did a long term monitoring to find out what part of his brain is causing them and found out it is his whole left side. He is coherent during his seizers and knows everything that is happening. His whole body will stiffen up and shake like with a grand mal but he can speak. He will cry and yell mom over and over until I get by his side. Then he just cries until it is done. Before a seizer happens his right leg will go numb and within 24 hours he will have one. Then immediately after and for about 5-10 minutes his right leg will be numb and he will be unable to move it or stand. When he has a seizer, he will normally have at least two within an hour of each other, but not always. The Dr still doesn't know exactly what is causing them, but now my son has to see a different Dr because his left.
