I am 53 right now & have had them since I was 16.I have petit mal seizures that happen once every month or so.Sometimes its a gap of 2 to four months between them.But when they happen,I am asleep somewhere between 8pm 8am & sometimes when I take the medication in the morning,like 7am,I will take my dose,go back to bed & start to feel a lightheaded headache & just sit in bed & do nothing or lay down with my head propped up on a pillow a little,have a few wheat crackers & a little ice-tea & think about what I have to do for the day the feeling slowly goes away or like this morning,I will wake,its in the 40s outside & feel hot all over & need to cool down.I take socks & blankets off & try to cool down.After a half hour or so,that feeling is gone I feel normal again.The sweats & hot feeling can wake me right up.I always have next to my bed,wheat crackers,a 16oz bottle of ice-tea,books & mag & my pill case.This to relax & take my mind off whats going on.Sometimes I go to work & feel better as the day goes on.If I have had one overnight,I know the next morning from a headache to I have bitten my tongue or the side of my mouth.I will relax & do nothing,maybe read,sleep & then the laptop.I have written alot,but its help this morning now to feel normal again.Its been about two months since the last attack & I would like to make it a four month gap.

Simple-Partial seizures really don't require any recovery time for me.  Unless you know me as well as my wife you won't even know that I am having a seizure.  And she only catches about half of them.  What helps me the most is to NOT focus on the S-P seizure and remember to breathe.  As soon as I start to focus on a S-P I am much more likely to push myself into a Complex-Partial.  There are no perfect answers.  Everyone has a different body so remember that.  Find what works best for you and never stop looking for a better way.

I have grand mal seizures. I am first confused then I remember shortly after. Then I sleep for a long time. I am weak like I just ran a marathon. I am seizure free now for 6 years. My longest since my first in 1999.

I drove after the doctors thought my epilepsy was under control since I had been seizure free for awhile. Then I had a massive absence seizure and rolled my car at 120mph in 8:00 rush hour traffic. I shattered my leg and had 30 operations on it in 4 years. The next surgery is an amputation. I wish the doctor had taken my license. I'm going to be an amputee because of driving with epilepsy. Btw- I've been seizure free after a temporal lobectomy 11 years ago.
If they don't want to allow me to drive, then I want disability. If I can't drive, I can't get to work. MS doesn't have adequate public transportation.

The state of NY now provides Medical Transportation. I've been through h*ll for over 4yrs trying to use this service & most of the time it does not seem worth it. If I drive I risk injuring other people. When walking (and this has happened several times) I risk having a seizure & NO ONE CALLS 911 even though they see me laying on the sidewalk convulsing. When I call Med. Trans. (it is used only for medical appts.) many times I am faced with rudeness, accusations of missing paperwork, questions that involve digging into my personal life. One of the most common questions is "Do you live within 1mile of a bustop?" And yes I do. Sometimes this ok, sometimes not. The problem with that: when people drive or walk right by you as if nothing is wrong when your life is in serious danger! So if I can't drive, and I would not want to anyway so as not endanger innocent people, what do I do? I walk as often as possible. But the options are slim when it comes to seeing my neurologist who is 2hrs away.
I think every state should be required to report you. I live in Texas and they are not.

Of course I lost my license and continue to have seizures. One dr says seizure free for a year, but my dr says she never wants me to drive again. My girls' beg me to please never drive. I will post this again and again to hopefully get this out to everyone. 
I was Diagnosed when I was 18yrs just like my mom. Grand-mal seizures and diagnosed as genetic. Here is what I have noticed with myself and wonder if this can help anyone else that may be born with this disease naturally. I am 36 now and must had a baby a year ago.
Here are some factors or things I have noticed. 
1. Hormonally related. Around my period cycle I get (what I call) seizure activity. My mother told me the doctors show on bt had a big debate about new talk about hormones. For me, this is a connection 100%.  I went on birth control (nuvaring since they don't have to up the dose of estrogen in that one). And I felt better!!! Being pregnant I had never felt better in my life and this includes of days of NO SLEEP which normally is a huge trigger for me! 
2. STRESS AND SLEEP is always a factor and always will be. I do my best to control and stay happy with Activities I enjoy, relaxing a lot and making sure I get plenty of sleep. 
3. DIET! CARBS!!!! Carbs are always told its a NO NO bc it makes you fat. WRONG. Your brain cannot function properly without carbs. Anabolic is the term used when your body is starved of these. Don't forget your brain needs these! Make sure your morning has them and keep them consistent through your daily meals!  I have felt seizure activity when I am low. Fast metabolism ppl really need to be careful. 
4. You all know alcohol is a bad idea. It's when the brain comes down from the buzz that you "detox" from the substance and that's when  you are seizure prone. 
Please feel free to contact me for more information on remedies you can do yourself to help. I won't clog up this post with a book lol. I hope this has helped anymore. God bless and stay safe everyone!!

During a simple partial seizure,  I would just have an aura. That was it. During a complex partial seizure,  I would have the usual aura followed by automatisms (uncontrollable automatic behavior), which I would have no memory of. There was almost always a strong feeling of the need to escape with a complex partial seizure. One time I was in a college class and had a seizure. Afterwards, I was told that I started making hiccup-like noises, got up, walked around the classroom, out the back door, walked around the building, and back into the main lobby where I sat down and recovered from the seizure. I freaked out some people that day. I had a complex partial seizure while riding in a car one time. I opened the car door and tried to get out at an intersection. Scary stuff.
Thanks for letting me know the differance. God bless.

I will post this again and again to hopefully get this out to everyone. 
I was Diagnosed when I was 18yrs just like my mom. Grand-mal seizures and diagnosed as genetic. Here is what I have noticed with myself and wonder if this can help anyone else that may be born with this disease naturally. I am 36 now and must had a baby a year ago.
Here are some factors or things I have noticed. 
1. Hormonally related. Around my period cycle I get (what I call) seizure activity. My mother told me the doctors show on bt had a big debate about new talk about hormones. For me, this is a connection 100%.  I went on birth control (nuvaring since they don't have to up the dose of estrogen in that one). And I felt better!!! Being pregnant I had never felt better in my life and this includes of days of NO SLEEP which normally is a huge trigger for me! 
2. STRESS AND SLEEP is always a factor and always will be. I do my best to control and stay happy with Activities I enjoy, relaxing a lot and making sure I get plenty of sleep. 
3. DIET! CARBS!!!! Carbs are always told its a NO NO bc it makes you fat. WRONG. Your brain cannot function properly without carbs. Anabolic is the term used when your body is starved of these. Don't forget your brain needs these! Make sure your morning has them and keep them consistent through your daily meals!  I have felt seizure activity when I am low. Fast metabolism ppl really need to be careful. 
4. You all know alcohol is a bad idea. It's when the brain comes down from the buzz that you "detox" from the substance and that's when  you are seizure prone. 
Please feel free to contact me for more information on remedies you can do yourself to help. I won't clog up this post with a book lol. I hope this has helped anymore. God bless and stay safe everyone!!

I was experiencing the De ja vu syndrome before I was diagnosed with a brain aneurysm my Dr at the time told me it was anxiety attacks it took her a few more months before sending me for a cat scan unfortunately my aneurysm ruptured and I ended up having to go in a medically induced coma to releive the pressure I woke up two months later and couldn't walk for two years   lost my job, car, everything finally just started walking again and my Dr is tapering me off my anti seizure meds as I have been seizure free for two years :-) new Dr also BTW new insurance as well

Ive had seizures all my life, and id have to disagree active pos is just as hard to live with as if u were having active tonic clonic. My partial seizures start as deja vu. Then I smell something in the air.  I lay down and have to close my eyes.  I can but talk while having the seizure.  I have a swallowing reflex because I feel nausea as if I will throw up.  Finally I have a thought in my head.  It's always the same thought however I can not remember the thought.  I'm also disoriented and tired afterwards.
I know when my first seizure was 25 years ago. It was that day at work when I had that sudden feeling of deja-vu. For some of us with epilepsy, that's not a good feeling.
It is so frustrating to live with these. Nobody can understand what we go through.

POS are surely easier to live with than generalized tonic clonic, but I find there's also less understanding from both doctors and peers. People hear seizure and have an idea what that looks like. POS don't fit that mold and are are often dismissed. Mine wouldn't respond to activation and a doctor wrote them off as PNES for the sake of a research thesis. 

After 6 years of POS I think the worst part for me is the doubt. So many doctors initially said it was psychiatric thst I actually doubted what was happening. Even with a diagnosis, there's still that lingering doubt.

I'm 20 now, and I've had POS since I was 9. I would always get a deja-vu feeling sometimes before, sometimes after my seizures, but they were always there. My seizures have been under control for about a year now, but multiple times a day, I feel like I'm starting to get that deja-vu feeling again. It kind of rises up as a feeling in my throat, but doesn't come all the way. It's like my body's teasing me. I'm nervous that my body may getting used to my medications again and that might be what's causing it, but I don't know. I hope not; I've been on tons of different meds already and have already considered surgery. (Was only put off because my seizures were better controlled). I've caught myself spacing out too. I'm still aware of everything around me, but I just have this urge to stare and I'll do it for what feels like 5 minutes. I tried asking the neuro about it, but I didn't get any answers. She didn't seem concerned when I told her. Should I be concerned?

I've had partial onset seizures all my life. Didn't know what it was so I never told anyone till after I was diagnosed with epilepsy at 17 when I started having petite mal seizures. Even then I didn't believe they were partial onset seizures I thought they were anxiety attacks but my doctor said because of the deja vu it sounded more like a partial onset seizure. Mind if I ask a question? Has anyone ever felt an intense feeling of doom and fear during a partial onset seizure or know of someone who has? I have a bunch of crazy symptoms during one but I don't think I've ever heard of anyone else having these two symptoms as well.

a couple yrs ago a friend found me in the middle of a field ....sweeping the grass with a kitchen broom.... in the rain.... thinking that was right where i belonged and what i was supposed to be doing.... i never have just one... so can be in status for hrs or even days... sometimes that means hallucinations ... sometimes that means blackouts.... they do occasionally generalize into convulsive seizures... those i will have in nasty clusters as well... as for the hallucinations...    
i have often had hallucinations of all 5 senses at once.....some times they hit in stages...almost like stacking upon one another..... tastes...smells....feelings....sounds....and finally the visions.......
and at times it will only be one or two senses....any combination is possible...

they come when they want...usually with little in the way of warning....

i hear voices as well...
always a womans voice.... 
sometimes singing...
sometime chanting....
but always repeating.....
a phrase...
or a few words....
always something of great meaning....always something i have always known but have a hard time remembering when i am not there......sometimes i will hear a cupple words together...someone saying them...irl or on tv/radio......
and the rest of the world fades back...becomes detached....and those cupple words just repeat....
first in the voice i heard them in ...then in her voice....
then as the vibrations rise in each and every cell...
the music comes....music i can feel as much as hear
 the taste comes...
and all the world turns red......
everything closes in from behind like a head rush gone bad......
blackness swarming and alive with stars closes in around me....
finally even this tears open ...and for just a moment...i am offered a look ...a peek ...into the place the music comes from
and then i am back here.....they always abandon me back to this world ....again and again......
what i wouldnt give to stay there!!!!!!!     - i could go on and on...how much you want to hear?
They are a form of seizure and should be guided like most even if its not a grand mal.It can become very bad also! I have had this since 1983!

I would be walking or playing and a situation would catch me, a buzzing feeling would start followed by this intense feeling like I hand been here before in some prior life, then a metallic tasting would fill my mouth, I break out into a sweat and sometimes it would over power me to ware  I could function and sometimes I could function through them.  As I aged I was able to control myself during the event.  I was a poor performer in school, some areas I did well such as history. I will be seizure-free for three years after five years of having one every month or two. My doctor said that I'll be considered to be in "remission" and I can start to taper off my anticonvulsants but that will never happen. I'll take them until I die if it means that I'm less likely to seize.
I lost my husband 07-10-2013, he had a seizure while driving.

Hubby was having "monents" for 9 months before he told me about them.  When he finally did, we got into see his PCP who set him up with a neurologist right away.  These "moments" stopped three days before we saw her, but he started on medication for the next 10 months, which depressed him horribly,  so when fall hit and he wasn't getting outside as much the depression got worse, he told his PCP that he had feelings of not wanting to live if this is how he was going to feel. So we saw his neurologist three months before the year was up being on that med, she weaned him off of it before we saw her. He was not having any of those "moments" at all since taking the meds, but without them, or some meds, there was always the chance of having another, and, perhaps having an accident.  That was enough for him to agree to continue taking some kind of meds for the possiblity.  Before meeting with the neuroologiest hubby did have an MRI which showed that on one side of his hippocampus near the base, there was an enlargement.  He will have another MRI in Feb to see if there is a change.  I asked her point blank if she saw any signs of Alzheimers and she said, not at this time, but if soemthing else, it is a very difficult area to remove something.  You have to be brave to get old, he is only 66.  Thanks for reading this, it helps me to put it in type.
even though I have not had a sesizure for a whole year I still know I have to take my meds just in case.
It's annoying that I can't even drive . But I rather not have seizure and crash.

Hello, my name is Walter, and I would like people to know that it is possible to overcome. I was diagnosed with epilepsy at the age of 15. I was having seizures at least once a month up till I was 25. I also had three grand mal seizures in that 10 year timespan. In 2005 I had a grand mal seizure that landed me in ICU for three days, and in the hospital for a a total of a week. Because of these seizures and state laws, I was not able to get my license to drive. People were telling me that I needed to get used to the fact that I may not ever be able to drive. But, I kept telling them that I would drive some day. To make an already log story short, In 2006 I finally got my drivers license. Also, I have not had a seizure since 2005, and  am not currently taking medication for it.

I just want people to know that you can overcome. Don’t let anyone tell you cannot do something because you have epilepsy. Epilepsy is something we have, not who we are.

Everybody has setbacks in life, but the way we deal with them defines our character and personality. I've noticed that people with Epilepsy as well as other chronic conditions overcome such great adversity, so now I believe there is no seizure, problem, or loss that this community can't bounce back from! Happy Epilepsy Awareness Month and God Bless!

First I’d like to say, thanks to everyone for having me here today and for making this Epilepsy awareness project happen! I don’t think there’s any way we can’t say that the world needs to be more aware of Epilepsy – we just can’t say it enough! I’m retired now and I spend a lot of time speaking with individual families and schools – basically anyone saying “I need a mentor – someone who has been here and lived through this.” When I was a young teenager, I would have given ANYTHING to have met someone that could give me guidance who knew what I was going through – but I didn’t get that until I was in my forties. That personal connection is so important. So I’m hoping today to be that resource for people going through what I went through.

Once you’ve reached Acceptance, you’re going to start asking yourself: “What are the things I can do to tell if I’m getting better or getting worse?” So I usually say: “If you don’t play to win, why keep score?” While this isn’t a game, we still want to win – so it’s important that we keep score! So what does that mean?

You MUST keep records of your seizure activity. Whether it’s daily or weekly, you need to find some way to keep records of: frequency, severity (how tough), time of day (asleep or awake), and any additional triggers – for me, I track relative stress level (for example, somewhere between 1 and 10).  You need to do one additional thing: it’s important that you can find a way to SUMMARIZE this at a level that is easily understandable by your physician. In my case, I’ve done it at monthly or quarterly levels (though I usually do monthly at this time). In these summarizations, you need to point out any particular changes you’ve had in your personal lifestyle (career changes, stressors, treatment changes, etc) so that you can see patterns that correlate to the activities around you. 

In this picture, you can see an example of a chart I’ve created over the years to share with my physician.

Our first question of the day is from Lisa-Marie W: “How do you explain epilepsy/ prepare your students for a possible seizure during the term?”

I first taught in a very rural area in Missouri in the mid 70s, so there was very little information or awareness of epilepsy. I actually never stood up in front of my students and told them “I have epilepsy” – the awareness just wasn’t there. I didn’t want to tell my students because I knew A) they wouldn’t understand and B) there was no way for them to really educate themselves about this disease (remember, this was the mid-70s!!). In my case, I would have about a 10 second aura warning. I would just exit the room and have my seizure in the hallway, collect myself, and then re-enter the room and make some excuse. In two years, I never had a student come up to me to ask what was actually wrong – and this happened to me roughly every two weeks for two years. If I did it today, I would certainly sit down first with my students and say “Today we aren’t going to talk about math – we’re going to talk about Epilepsy.” I would want to talk through exactly what epilepsy is and what it means to me. I may even let the students watch me have a partial-onset seizure at some point just so that they could learn and have first-hand knowledge since so few people actually know about epilepsy.

When I speak with patients across the country, I like to focus on 5 important factors: 
-	Acceptance
-	Keeping Score
-	Predicting
-	Playing by the Rules
-	Should I give up?

I’ll touch on Acceptance first. It doesn’t matter if you’ve been recently diagnosed or were diagnosed 10 years ago, at some point you’ll go through the 5 stages of grief: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, and finally Acceptance. Throughout the first 3 stages, your seizures are still there; and when you move into depression (which you will likely do), your body may respond with increased seizure activity purely as a factor of enhanced stress. 

Until you finally Accept the fact that you have Epilepsy, then (in my opinion) you’re never going to be able to take charge of the problem yourself and be able to take important steps to correct this. “I accept it; I know I have it; NOW what can I do?”

When I was younger, I played basketball and would have seizures on the court. My coach would burn a time-out and get me off the court. After that, he would check on me throughout the game to see how I was feeling and see when I was ready to go back in. This was the same case for baseball, football, etc. Today, people learn they have epilepsy, then go online and find so much information that it can scare them. In my case, I had people in my life who were willing to sit with me and learn what was happening to me and push me to be better – as opposed to just assuming the worse. 

We ended up discovering exactly what was happening to me when I was in seventh grade: we saw a public service announcement on TV that showed “little Johnny” having a seizure on TV and I said to my mom “that’s exactly what happens to me every day” – from that point on we started doing the research it would take to find a way to make me better! My parents gave me an option: they said, do you want to stop doing these things you’re doing or do you want to work hard? I wanted to keep doing these fun activities that I was doing and the only way to do that was to keep on pushing for better treatment. My parents were true mentors for me – they pushed me to keep finding ways to improve my condition.

This concludes today's session! I want to thank everyone for spending their day with us! My main message is to never give up and that you must play by the rules if you’re going to succeed. Playing by the rules means working hand-in-hand with your physician to figure out the right path for you and sticking with that; while at the same time making sure you’re putting yourself in the best situations to manage your epilepsy! Thanks to everyone for your time today and we look forward to continue connecting with you all in the future!

Once you’ve started tracking your seizure activity, you can begin to notice important patterns and/or triggers. For me, stress is a major trigger. My normal stress level is at a 5 – if I’m sitting at that normal stress level, my seizure activity is normal for me. Now, if I suddenly take on new projects and my stress level spikes to an 8 or 9, then my seizure activity wouldn’t change significantly either. This was good. Unfortunately, as soon as my stress level DROPPED (let’s say down to a 2), then my seizure activity would go up significantly. So it wasn’t during a stressful time that seizures happened – it was actually after the stressful periods when it occurred. For instance, when I was playing basketball, my seizures would occur during time outs or during free throws because the stress had stopped. 

So what does that mean for me now? I have learned how to step myself down from my high stress level down to a normal stress level to avoid the large drops that trigger increased seizure activity. I work to keep my stress levels fairly consistent and avoid significant up-and-down swings in stress. This is the pattern I learned about myself by observing my charts and data – it will be different for any of you for sure, but that’s how it works for me.

The best route to ANY successful treatment for seizures is JOURNALING! I've lived with this battle my entire life and nothing helped me more than A DOCTOR THAT LISTENS & A JOURNAL with date, time, activities, and before/after symptoms. .....

I have nothing but praise for those that care for those suffering from epilepsy     I am one of the fortunate . I was diagnosed with Epilepsy at age 5 suffered from Petite and Gran Mal siezures I went through the battery of medications with varying results I was a regular at Harbor view epi-center and was put on a federal blind drug study for tranzene at the age of 16 ,my seizures diminished, the program ended when I was 18 but I continued on the medication , by just after my 21st Bday I was seizure free . By age of 27 I was off meds- I am now 55  still seizure free, whether the meds kick started something or I simply grew out of my siezures I do not know, I have had numerous EKGs over the years and all seems to be normal. For all the family and friends ( and the local fire dept) I give thanks as  Epilepsy effects all of those around them.

My mom was 13 years old in 1952, and several things happened that year:.  Hard to picture now, but Mom was a bit of a tomboy in those days.  She liked to play with her two brothers, both younger, who of course did Not want to play with big sister.  They decided, "Let's play follow the leader on our bikes.  That'll lose her."  They jumped a ditch, Mom got scared and slowed down, fell off and broke her arm.  She started her period that year, and she was in the shower when she had her first seizure.  Ganna(my grandma) found her, and man she was freaked.  She'd barely even heard of epilepsy.  
Also in that year, they moved from a house to basically an empty lot.  The five of them lived in their garage for the first year or two.  They carried everything in the kids' little red wagon, on foot; no one helped them.  Perhaps all related to Mom's epilepsy, maybe not.  Mystery.

I'm so sorry for your loss, and I feel your pain and frustration.  So few people realize that Epilepsy can be life-threatening.  I lost my sweet baby girl at age 4...from SUDEP (sudden unexplained death due to Epilepsy).  She passed in her sleep and we found her the next morning.  It was devastating.

attending "Epilepsy Awareness Day at Disneyland Resort" with my "Service Dog" named: ALEPO and educating the public about "Epilepsy" and how "Service Dogs" help me fight my battle.

Wearing purple every day and then explaining why to all the people who ask me!  It has been fun to share this in a new city!  I'm getting lots of questions and getting to tell a lot of new people about epilepsy!

People keep asking about the Kansas State hat I'm wearing. I wear it for November and I've gotten a lot of attention here in Dallas. I tell them, "This is Epilepsy Awareness Month, and purple is our color." I've answered questioned and found others who have family and friends with epilepsy.
In loving memory of my mother, Shirley Shull, who had severe epilepsy. If you knew my mom, please wear purple at least once this month!!
By having a good neurologist, a great support team in my wife, and educating about the kind of seizures I have so the proper treatment plan is in place. Praise God I have all of the above.
posting articles and other awareness links through my facebook! I'm already helping spread the awareness!

I co-own a dance company - my director's solo at this past Saturday's annual variety show included many of the movement's I do pre, mid, and post seizure (post dictal) of my absent, petite, and grand-mal's. The song stated "Blame it on the night, don't blame it on me" (acoustic version ) as my convulsive seizures only come at night and my guilt of night time for myself and family is deep...The song ended abruptly before anyone would of thought, just as some normal days or nights do for some of us. The choreography was simple and I did not execute it to mu fullest potential in several parts, as sometimes I cannot live to my fullest potential. I had a friend in the audience who was recently diagnosed, and her girlfriend in my company had purple streaks in her hair. <3

I am spreading awareness by selling purple bracelets and donating the money to the epilepsy foundation of America. I also have my entire school wearing purple every Wednesday to support epilepsy awareness and I'm challenging my family and friends to donate $20 to the epilepsy foundation of America and I am thanking those people by taking a pie in the face with each donation to help #SmashOutEpilepsy

To learn more about reporting side effects, please visit our Adverse Events Reporting tab. Remember you can always report any side effects that you experience directly to your doctor and the FDA by visiting www.FDA.gov/medwatch or by calling 1-800-FDA-1088.

Just let me be , let me gather myself and let me continue on with my daily routine.i don't like to be "babied " 
It is what it is. Let the seizure do its thing and we can carry on .

I usually sleep, when I wake up, my husband will remind me that I've had a seizure, answers my questions and makes me lay Down or rest where I will relax, most of the time I sit in my recliner next to him, as I gradually remember everything that led up to the seizure. I take cocoanut oil gel tabs, 100% pure, within two weeks after I started taking these I was able to retain my memory, remembering things I had long forgotten - even remembering, at times. being in the middle of a seizure. I have Gran Mal seizures. But these gel tabs have worked wonders with my memory! 
I don't let my seizures keep me from going after what I want or allow it to stop me from trying new things. I wasn't born with epilepsy, but started having them at 13 years old, I've had them for over 43 years. I have a career, husband, two children and five grandchildren. Don't let someone tell you, you -CAN'T until you've at least tried. <ed><U+00A0><U+00BD><ed><U+00B8><U+008A>
Mine are grand Mal, it takes at least a day for me to recover

Idk if this is the right place to post this, but I cannot find a way to message you/ the peeps of said advocates. I am an 8 year veteran of Graphic Design, and would love to do either Pro-Bono or paid graphic design/ graphic arts for this group. I have had epilepsy for 13 years, caused by Dercum's Disease, I also am, as my doctor put it..."that one in a billion type of patient that the medical journal doesn't apply to" as I had epilepsy disappear from my world and then reappear in a two distinctly different types of seizures vs. what I suffered from prior to it "disappearing" both in my EEG( I am a person with an EEG reading of less than 9,000, compared with standard epileptics whose reading is 13,000+, which again my neurologist said is impossible according to medical journals et cettera)  and in my life. I am one who has done severe damage to my body thanks to clonic-tonic seizures (for example: fracturing my humerus, dislocating both of my shoulders, cracking my eyebrow and chin on the hard edge of a marble counter-top, and MANY other injuries). Seizures/ Epilepsy has had a strong impact on my self-confidence that has taken me years to recover from and reassert my self-confidence and love for myself, as I have soiled myself in public situations, such as when I accompanied my sister to one of her clients house, and have had seizures right as I was beginning to have intercourse; talk about awkward!

My partial seizures I can feel coming on by my thinking.  I notice it, unsure, but watch it increase & peak after about 5 minutes. sabrina:  i had seizures for 25 years.  during that time i had over 400 jobs faced bullying and outright discrimination in everyone of them.  before the diagnosis i was a machinist in an area that even in the 50's was highly technical.  after that instead of making 20.00 per hour i made 2.00 an hour.    i went into training thru illinois vocational rehab in 1963 i was trained to rebuild electrical motors.  this was a field i could never be employed in and voc rehab closed there ears to any request for advocacy.  i was 21 when i was diagnosed  in  1962.   in 1981 i went thru brain surgery in chicago a begnine tumor was removed andi have been seizure free since.  i was fired for being well 3 days after this surgery.i had been with the company for 11 years.  my family disowned me after all these years because of constant depression.  i have 4 grand children i will never know.   I have accepted this as reality for my life and sticking around just to see what else can happen.

Hey Guys, A while back I wrote a little poem, I will Post it here, I would really like to know what you think(It may be looked at as negative, but plenty of us are still climbing the ladder towards 'wondering when and if' the people around us will really accept us despite our condition. Let me know what you think and feel because either in our past and even now, I still have these emotions on what I need to do to be considered 'ME'  I titled it 'You Can Call Me'....5/23/2014
 You Can Call Me...

When you're not expecting it,
I can take control
Grasp your mind, thoughts, and body
given enough time, I can pull your heart from your soul.

When you're out and about,
I can make look like a fool
embarrass you outright
Because you are just my tool.

I am always here with you,
And I refuse to leave
I'm right here on your shoulder, 
right on your sleeve.

I can take you anytime,
Yes anytime I want
I can introduce my self at any given moment
My power have I can always flaunt.

I have been called many things,
you can cuss me at your leisure 
Yes, I have many names, 
But you can call me seizure

Written by Brian Spratley
5/23/2014

I, like everyone here, has a story. Everyone's is unique to each individual. My self, have had epilepsy since I was 13yrs old(I am 40 now). Lost jobs, suspended(or revoked) Driver's License, I can't remember, it's been so long. I haven't driven since 1999. Been on disability ever since. But unable to drive or work, I still found something I love to do AND make money too. I am now a professional photographer. I am able to to do shoots at my time, when I feel comfortable. I'm not told when or how to do something. I am my own boss! I write my own schedule. So if anyone out there is unable to be successful in the general  workforce, Find something unique to you and begin your own business. So many things you can do, things that come so natural, even to the point you don't even realize you are unique. There are people out there that need what you can do and are willing to pay for your abilities simply because they can't accomplish what you can. If it's a simple service you can offer or a every day thing that you have a strong potential doing, people need it. Find your market, aim for that market, and fulfill the needs and wants of that market.

It is definitely hard not to let Epilepsy, define who I am when people look at financial risks in hiring me, here in the USA.  With all the medical lawsuits that are going on and are allowed to go on, I would rather work where I have been accepted as a competant worker and not as a risk. I am a survivor because, a small country like Danmark let me move there and finish school and helped me with my education until I was 23, I then worked hard at a factoring company owned by a group of Danish banks, There I worked AR and saw something that needed improvement and told my dept.leader, who tried to take credit for it, but I went straight to th president of the company and I was put in charge of  improving the customer lists and consistant sorting of accounts, It gave me enough to buy me an apartment and later move back to the USA.  I thought I would get treated just as fairly and justly, but We the People have a long long way to go in EQUALRIGHTS. for ALL CITIZENS of this country.

I'm a 38 year old chemical engineering student, mom to the two most perfect and amazing Korat cats, a pretty loving girlfriend, and I have epilepsy. I have the pleasure of only having grand mal seizures, no variety. My first happened completely out of the blue in 2004, and I injured myself pretty badly. They always last at least ten minutes and have been getting longer with each successive one. I have had 14 concussions, broken my nose twice, dislocated both shoulders, broken one wrist so badly that it required surgery, and numerous painful bruises and cuts. I'm blessed that I have an aura of about 1-2 seconds, so a couple of times I've been able to prevent injury from the seizure by getting to the floor, and the one time I had one while driving, I was able to pull over to safety beforehand. Epilepsy has taken a lot from me: my career as a transit driver in Minneapolis, my ability to play video games, seeing live concerts, this intangible and unexplainable feeling of safety and well-being. You never know when or where you'll be when the next one happens, and uncertainty causes stress for me, and stress increases the frequency of the seizures and intensifies the chronic pain I have from the injuries sustained during seizures. Thankfully, I've found a combination of medications that control my seizures really well; I used to have them every few weeks and now I'm approaching my second year free of seizures. They're very expensive: even as generics, the monthly cash price is more than $500. I hate that I have to depend on money from the government (in the form of an insurance subsidy) to be able to buy my medications, I took great pride in being a self-sufficient, tax-paying, productive citizen, and now I'm dependent. I'm afraid that my hard work in engineering school will be a waste, because what if I have a seizure and I'm working in a chemical plant? I've been fortunate and have always lived where doctors are not required to report seizures to the DMV, so I've never lost my license, but will I be legally able to work in the settings that a chemical engineer would work in? I really love this page, you all are so inspirational, thank you all for sharing your stories!

I am 42 yrs old, a wife, mother of 2 beautiful boys who 5 yrs ago when this all happened out of nowhere thought their mommy was dying.  I was in ICU for a month and barely knew who I was, I lost years of memory that will never come back and everyday is hard.  I couldnt read, write, walk, and now I have become a certified Yoga teacher.  I will not stop fighting.  I have done charity evnts for the past 4 yrs, I do have a facebook page and website that I havent updated recently but its called "journeyforfaith" My name.  My mom said in the hospital, I guess I named her for a reason.  I am on 3-4 medicines and had a VNS put in.  Still not working.  I am going up to NY in the next few mth for tests and then to have surgery, others are scared....me....just get me on the table. You dont walk in my shoes.  Each seizure just makes you feel bad physically and emotionally.  I wont let epilepsy define me, but its been a rough month... Im just not doing great, my Yoga has been a gift and my place I can go to when I just need to be and breathe and let it go.  There is a universe up there, I believe that, not sure why all this happened at the age of 38 but I definitely changed as a person and realize whats important... Got rid of all things toxic... Now its time for me to get better, I have 2 boys, one turning 10 Saturday and the other 12.  They need their mommy....
as an advocate don't shine off people.  they need to voice feelings.  keep this in your mind "feelings are never right or wrong.  they just are"  RESPONDING WITH YOUR FEELINGS WORKS BETTER.

I'm the oldest child, brother to 4 sisters, full-time college student (studying computer science), part-time employee, ice hockey goalie, and a bit of a geek.  I have Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy and it doesn't change a thing.

I am a dancer, choreographer, hiker, wife, mother to two amazing felines, and an advocate for education/awareness, tolerance, and empathy.  I got epilepsy the same year as I was accepted into the Joffrey Ballet - a dream cut short too soon.  It took over 30 years for my epilepsy to get to the control level I am at now.  I never thought that I would be dancing, let alone performing, again.  Yet, at the age of 50 I began studying dance again after a 25-year hiatus and find myself in my mid-50's in a new dance community and dance troupe.  Epilepsy has made me a strong, empathetic woman.  I just recently joined this community.  Thank you for your encouragement and support.

I have been a wife for five yrs now but with my love for fifteen yrs.  We have one son together (14), I have a son (19), and my husband has three - two boys (19 & 17) and a girl (18).  At their ages you can feel them slipping away into adulthood and it is hard sometimes, there will never be enough time in the world to spend with them.  We are total animal lovers with three dogs, one cat, and sixteen birds!!  They are all an extension of our family; some talk, some play, some cuddle, and some have truly been a comfort to me.  I love helping others and felt I had found a my true calling in the medical office field, even got my BA in Health Care Administration with a GPA I never expected out of myself :-)  My life changed early January 2010 when I had my first grand-mal ever at the age of 32.  Even though I tried so hard not to I lost my job, I lost the independence of driving myself around, and I started to swirl down the rabbit hole of depression.  I still am not medically released to return to work or drive, but I mentally fight allowing epilepsy to define me everyday.  Honestly, it has made me look for my own self worth in places other than work, it has made me appreciate everyday I wake up and don't have my husband stairing scaredly in my eyes, and it has made me more aware of every blessing I am given.  
It is comforting to read your stories and see more strength and/or ideas as to how others can find help.  Good luck to everyone reading and posting, may you all have a great day.

I have a question....my dog is not a "trained seizure" dog....but he seems to sense when I am about to have a seizure.  Is this possible?  TOO many times I have been with him and he has started staring at me barking and it was right before I went into a seizure.  My boyfriend declares it is too many times not to be that the dog is sensing the seizures beforehand.  This dog is an extremely unusual dog in nature already.  We have raised him from a puppy and he is four years old.  He is overly smart and unusual.  But I have seizures OFTEN,,,,usually just the smaller seizures.....I don't have but the grand mals but about once a month if that often,  But the absence seizures....I may have several a day if there are high pressure systems....but If I am around that dog....he seems to sense it....he will just sometimes stare at me and stay close to me.....like he has to protect me.....its strange.  Didn't know if it was my imagination.....or if it was possible????? without training?  Perhaps he has just been with us long enough that he can just tell I am sickly those days because it does make me very weak.  Just curious....  But he seems to know it BEFORE they start is the weird thing....BEFORE I do oftentimes.....   Oh....his name is T-Bone....LOL....he is half Rhodesian Ridgeback and half Red Nose Pit ....a very unique one of a kind dog....the Vet loves him!!!  =)

I have, for the most part given up.  I was diagnosed about 12 years ago, and in that time, I've seen 4 different neurologists, and all have said different things about my condition, and between those doctors, I've been on about 15 different medications, none of which seem to do the trick with me.  I'm on three right now.  I've had the VNS since September of 2012, and things just seem to be getting worse with my condition. Whenever I would have a seizure, and the magnet for the VNS would be used, 90% of the time it doesn't work.  The thing I hate most about my condition is that I NEVER know when the seizures are coming on. , I've been on permanent disability since 2010 for my condition, got approved for SSD 2 months later, and just started my full SSD this month.  I had a horrible car accident 4 years ago due to a seizure, & DMV said I'd never be able to drive again, even if I'm seizure free for a year.   It seems that I've lost my best friend, and a lot of friends besides her, b/c I can't drive, and they don't want to take the time to drive a measly 10-15 to come to my house.  I'm just thankful that I still have a great friend I can count on whenever I need him.

I am 55 and have never been able to drive. I went through brain surgery 5 years ago. When I woke from sugery everyone wanted to know how I was feeling. The first thing out of my mouth was can I go back to work and the drs said no. I asked it I was going to be able to get my drivers licence now and again they said no. I have gone 4 years without a seizure. Working and driving are stressful situations, and I can not be under any stress of it could trigger a seizure. After 50 years of uncontrolled seizures I am seizure free. I'll take not having seizures over driving any day. I wish I could drive tho. Having to depend on others is a pain, I don't like to have to ask for help.

I've been fortunate to have always lived in states where it's not mandatory that the doctor report your seizures to the DMV. My seizures suddenly started for no reason when I was 28, and I was a full-time city bus driver. I lived alone and owned my home, I needed my job! I realize now how irresponsible this was, but I kept working (driving) until 2006, when I came clean with my employer. I was hoping to be able to get a different job within the company, but it wasn't so. That's been the only real job I've had, I was there for over ten years. So, I'm having to retrain myself for a whole new career…  but that means going to engineeing school, and an 86 mile one-way commute. Thankfully, I've been seizure-free since January 19, 2013 and my meds keep them controlled, to the point where if I stopped taking my meds, I could predict the next seizure to within hours. I live in New Orleans, in a suburban area with poor bus service, yet it's still too dangerous to be out as a single female. I have a 1-2 second aura before the seizures start, and that has saved me from injuries more than a few times. I'm terrified of what may happen, I know that I won't likely live out my life seizure-free, but I don't know how I'd get anywhere if I can't drive, since my support system is virtually nonexistent.

I have not driven for 15yrs.Hard since I had driven since16yrs.old.My friends are so good to take me every where I need to go.Dr.will not allow me to drive and I still would love to get out on my own but noway.Would not risk someone else life that would be so selfish of me.

I have epilepsy,  it began getting worse about 6 years ago.   I have a unusual case, in that there are two different parts of my brain,  in different areas,  one on either side of my brain.  I am also struggling with the mood swings.   It is affecting my relationship with my fiance,  along with our 3 year old son.   We're starting a business slowly,  however I am becoming more forgetful daily.   It is beginning to become more depressing,  and the outbursts are happening more often. . The emotions are becoming more than we can handle. .   My neurologist tells me it's a side effect of the medication,  however she has been questionable on several occasions before.   I'm happy to find out more about this topic,  so I can deal with it more easily.   Also,  because of the extent of my case,  a lot of the medication has failed in the past. I worked as an 'ADA Workplace Reasonable Accommodation' specialist, in the HR dept of the City of SF Municipal Transportation Dept; became very familiar w/ ADA workplace law.  But, when I requested my own accommodation - a slightly modified work schedule, so I could catch the once an hour bus back home as I'd lost my driver license after a series of gran mal seizures -- I was denied.  All they had to say is "undue burden" or "unreasonable"; they are not required to specify how or in what way.  Thanks in part to my own efforts, accommodations were made to many other employees -- if/when the 'managerial will' was there --  but I'd become known as too much of an 'advocate' for my clients/the ADA process, and they wanted to get rid of me.. and so they did. I consulted the Jeanne A Carpenter Epilepsy Legal Defense Fund noted above, but they were never able to help me.  Every atty I consulted said employers can do whatever they want, and reminded me that ADA law is only as good as those who abide by it..  very disappointing
I was doing my internship had a seizure in the medical field and now I can't get a job anywhere in the field.
more states need to get on board with this.. It is very dangerous to drive and have seizures..

Though evidently not required in Texas, when my neurologist found out I was still driving even though my seizures were not under control, he gave me 24 hours to turn my license into the DMV or he would report me.  I was FURIOUS at the time, but Thank the Lord the doctor did so. I would hate to think what might have happened over the years to others on the road, including family and friends, even me, had I continued to drive.  Yes, it's inconvenient at times, and takes me a lot longer to get from point A to point B than I like, but with help from family, friends, and public transportation, I can get anywhere I need to go, I just have to plan ahead.  If your seizures are not 100% controlled, DO NOT DRIVE!!!  You'll survive.  I've been doing it now for 25 years.

I gave up my drivers license twelve years ago and I also had to give up my working career (at twenty-four years on the job) as result of my epilepsy (seizures). I could never risk hurting or possibly killing someone due to "my" disability. It hasn't been easy, but I know that I made the right move.
It is sad that it's harder to get drunks off the road.  One should also remember that people with heart conditions prone to passing out are not required to be reported nor are diabetics.

This needs to be the law in Every state!! After having a right frontal lobectomy 4 years ago, I've been seizure free and no meds. But that's AFTER I almost killed myself (and quite possibly could have been someone else if other cars were around) bc I insisted I had my epilepsy 'under control' and had aura. Only takes 30 seconds of unconscious to kill someone. I thank God everyday for that guardian angel. I will continue to support epilepsy foundation and this needs to be one law taken very seriously!

Yea! I still do, I love the feeling you get with exercise. Anything your angry about gets released into your health and it helps me by putting that stress somewhere healthy and more focused. It also helps me narrow my focus on the situation instead of being overwhelmed by the problem.

No yoga or tai chi but especially in the winter months I join exercise groups at the local Y. Spin class can be a great calorie burner and stress relief. In warmer months I personally prefer to be outdoors so I focus on bicycling, running and kayaking. Choose an exercise you enjoy and is safe for your personal situation. Consult a doctor first if you have not been exercising. Any exercise is a great stress relief and will improve your health.

Definitely yes and I echo what everyone else has suggested since stress can be a major trigger. Exercise, yoga, tai chi all help to maintain healthy oxygenated blood to your brain, centers you spiritually and psychologically,  and diverts your energy and fears away from our conditions.  My only additional suggestion would to be sure to wear or place an order to have some sort of medical alert bracelet or necklace which states your condition with access to additional important information regarding meds, emergency contacts and phone numbers including MD names in case something should happen during. This way not only are you doing something beneficial to improve your mind and body,  but gives you the additional protection of safety should you be out in the gym or running/walking in the community.

yes!  they (yoga, jacuzzi, swimming, mild cardio) continue to help me in the pursuits of a healthy lifestyle.  stay in touch with your medical team and do not deviate from the plan.  This is responsible for keeping me seizure free for years.

If your seizures aren't 100% controlled, DO NOT DRIVE!!!  A relative of mine who is a fire fighter and paramedic, has made runs to multiple auto accidents, where a person with epilepsy, who's seizures were not fully controlled, ended up severely injured or dead, and severely injured or killed someone else in the process.  He's even seen some of the people with epilepsy arrested, because they were driving without a license, caused an accident while having a seizure, but were not injured, though the driver/passenger/s in the other vehicle was/were.  IT'S    A G A I N S T   THE LAW!!!  Don't take the chance of ruining/ending your life or the lives of others.  Sadly, I'm speaking from personal experience.  I was one of the ones with seizures that were not 100% controlled, who continued to drive at the expense of someone else's health and welfare.  Thankfully - that's hard for me to say - when my neurologist found out I was still driving, he made me surrender my license to the highway patrol.  He even checked with them to make sure I had.  I haven't driven since 1989, I live in one of the top ten largest cities in the country, but with public transportation, help from friends and family, and good old healthy walking, I can get anywhere I want/need to go.
I don't drive

My seizures were under control & I had a grand mal driving. My license was taken away. I had to go before a jury at the DMV one year later. I haven't had a grand mal since, but it shows that even when they are under control you never know. I also just bought an electric blanket, but I keep hearing that you can't use them if you have epilepsy. I would hate to repeat history.

I, so, agree with Tim....I obtained my driver's license in 1975, & had no driving issues until 2005. I was over stressed from caring for an ill parent, plus trying to complete my master's degree. One morning I left home to run errands, only to have a seizure while driving, & found myself submerged in a body of water. I was lucky. God wasn't ready for me, yet! And, yes, I did not drive, again, until my seizures were under control. Since I lived in a mid-sized community, with limited epilepsy expertise, I relocated to a large metropolitan area, & now have a superb epileptologist.  Until my seizures were under control, I learned to use the train & bus systems. Plus, I've always been an avid walker. Today I am driving, and plan on returning to my hometown within the next 2 weeks. I will continue to see my epileptologist --- 200 miles away.  Should my condition provoke uncontrolled seizures, I will not be driving --- period! It's not worth losing a life!
So true many won't give you one at all and others have strong restrictions. I know because I've been there done that

The onset of mine is more of a mystery than their triggers are.  My suspicion is a form of a birth defect.  From what my sister told me a few years back, my mom had been as sterile as hospital sheets when she tried to have me.  Then, all of a sudden, in 1972 she was pregnant.  I had one neurologist back in 1981 who suggested that it may have been caused by a possible stroke during birth.  Fast-forward technology about 30 years later, and my current neurologist disagrees with that prognosis.  Saying that a stroke typically leaves scar tissue behind.  But, according to my latest MRI, there was no scar tissue to support the stroke theory.  So, again, we have what may be the cause but no definitive proof of exact cause.

The ADA is worthless to people with Epilepsy.  Employers can fire someone with Epilepsy, without making any accommodations, for a million reasons as long as they don't blame the firing on your Epilepsy.

It always help me to just close my eyes and sleep for a little bit in a dark room just like recharging my battery.

Partial seizures for me I just stay laying down in my bed or stay sitting down where ever I am until it stops.  Full blown seizures are different story if I have thoughs then lots of sleep .

Time. Sometimes food. I seem to have more when my blood sugar drops.
sleep

I cannot sleep after a seizure,  I have kids. I just take a few minutes to breathe
Sleep.   I must nap or go to bed for the night.  I can sleep for a long time after a seizure.
depends on what type I have time and rest for some . taking a walk for others. I have even stood in the shower for hours to try to help. People don't seem to understand and look at you like a freak!

I just started w/the partial seizures, I've had the grand mal for 12 yr but was 8 yr.s free of them, seems that stress is a big factor of bringing them on & I get a funny feeling in my stomach prior to having one, yet my Dr. says it's not Epilepsy?
Orange juice or ice water. Then just sit still for a while. But I come around faster with cold drink and air or fan on.
Peace and quiet, sleep as much as needed.

When I have the "absence" seizures I need to take an emergency pill and then lay down for about an hour while trying to avoid going into a gran mal seizure. Usually I am ok after that but maybe extra tired. When I have a grand mal seizure sometimes I don't remember having one and don't know where I'm at or that I have been sleeping for hours. But I remember once I realize that I have chewed deeply into my tongue. That's the worst.
Also
I usually have a hard time breathing after alsi

I never really remember mine but someone is always around me when I have one thank god! and I can't breath after I have one I know that and I always make a strange noise before I have one. I sleep after I do have one though.
I have pretty much every seizure there is and rest and my family to calm me down helps. I'm getting older now so it takes longer to recover now it seems.

Just my fiance talking me thru it..calming me down
When I have a seizure I lose consciousness. Afterwards I just sleep that's the only thing that helps.

I have no idea. All I known is I have no warning signs. I just go out. I have gran mal seizures and the only time I've had a ct scan it came from the right rear air mastoid. When I come to I have memory loss, am very sore the next few days and am pretty irritated for the next few minutes after. That's all I know.

I have been diagnosed with epilepsy for 7 years now, but my neurologist says I have probably had it all my life just hadn't recognized the sign til it progressively got worse with age and not being medicated til now. See when in grade school my teachers would say that I would day dream alot and wouldn't pay attention in class,  but my doctor now thinks I could have been miss diagnosed back then when really I could have been having absence seizures all along.  I still do have many absence seizures a day along with my partial complex ones. 
But I too through the years have learnt to control my seizures,  and tell my brain to basically to take the seizure away with out having to go through all the whole episode of having a full fledge attack and get embarrassed because people don't understand what's going on,  nor know how to help. 

Which I find is hard sometimes now that I have gone back to college.  I try to keep my epilepsy to myself because I am scared of judgment that was so tough for me when I was in high school.  :-(
after more than 40 yrs of experience, i get really tired, really fast, lose all appetite, meticalic taste, all before, if i control breathing, sometime i can stop..

Canine Assistants doesn't ask for recipients to do any fund raising for their dogs. All their dogs are sponsored through fund raisers and private and corporate sponsors. You fill out an app and they contact you when app is received and ask you more detailed questions. You are then added to a wait list that can take anywhere from 1-5 yrs. THESE ARE NOT A SIGN OF WEAKNESS!  Auras are like blanking out of life for a few seconds and not really knowing that you did it, however there are times when you do know it but you totally do not know what you were just talking about or possibly even where you are.  Then the fact that you can have the kind when there is no one around.  However, with medicine and/or surgery they are making progress every day.  Every day/week/month can always get brighter looking at everything, not just my everyday epilepsy.  Everything is a challenge, you just face it on and say SCREW IT and move on.  You keep trying and don't ever let it knock ya down.
I experience auras , there kinda like a warning where I need to stop what I'm doing and sit down before I hurt myself wen something big happens

yes I do it feels like an out of body thing something I don't like to feel

My son gets a nauseous feeling in his stomach, his face goes pale, he swallows over and over, and his speech slows. I get dizzy, my body starts to tingle, short of breah I get hot and break out in a sweat. Sometimes I just get tremors first

My 9 year old daughter has experienced these for close to two years.  They present to her as "rainbows" and during the episode her eyes shift to the left and stay there, or as she describes it, her eyes are watching the rainbows.  This usually lasts 2 minutes at the most before she becomes very nauseated and vomits.  She will sleep for an hour or so immediately following one of these episodes as her body drains of all energy.  Even though they are 90% controlled with medication, she will still have a random episode every few months or so.
She sees her neurologist in March. Hopefully he will be able to have some answers. But we live in such a rural area that he is the only pediatric neurologist in our area.

My lips go numb and have a strange feeling up the back of my neck. At that time using the magnet stops most of it just the speech is a little screwed up

I dont recall auras but everyone whose seen me have one say I make a face and a really scary noise.. my seizures went from lasting under a minute to lasting 2-5min..all mine are grand mal.. but I think in the last cpl weeks I been having wat I think are staring seizures dont know real name... not sure tho...

I have someone who takes me to all of my drs. appt. and I tild this family member that from now on STAY IN THE DABBLASTED WAITING ROOM!  THIS IS MY DRS. APPTS. ABOUT ME, NOT YOU!  I DON'T NEED YOU INTERRUPTING ME,  TO TALK ABOUT YOUR HEALTH! AND ADDING BITS AND PIECES ABOUT THINGS YOU HAVE NO IDEA ABOUT, ESPECIALLY SINCE YOU DO NOT EVEN LIVE WITH ME!!!!!!!!
After I told my father off he not permitted in any drs. appts., nor any drs. treatments, physical therapy or anything dealing with ANY DRS. that talk to me. Even if it is in th ER. I TOLD HIM, IF THAT HURTS YOUR FEELINGS, I'M JUST EXPRESSING HOW I FEEL, AND HOW SOME DRS. HAVE  EXPRESSED TO ME, WHILE  YOU ARE BEING THE ROOM DURING MY TREATMENTS.  YOU ARE DISRUPTING THEM, AND CAUSING THEM TO CUT MY TIME IF WHAT THEY NEED TO ASK,  OR DO! 
SO.......after that nice little conversation,  he waits I the waiting room, or if something happens, and he is needed,  then he is allowed. He is not permitted to even read what I may have to sign, nor is he permitted to speak on my behave if we are in the ER, and I can't speak, like when I had my Stroke in 2012. I tried to sign, but it was hard since I was paralysed on one side of my body, but it was just my left side,  but I did what I could with my right. Once my brother came to the ER,  he was able to translate, since I taught him when he was younger, and he still remembered,  and he sometimes has to use it for his job, and he knows my body language, considering he lives with me. So he, and my mother know my body language without me saying a word, since I do live with my Mother.  She works, since I am disabled with a lot of things, while my father is, I guess disabled, but he doesn't work, so that's my transportation. I also have a degree in Emergency Medical Philosophy. People at the Epilepsy Council in the city I live in assume Paramedics know practically nothing about seizures.
I felt like asking her how many people she's seen go into a seizure and then treated them for it. 
It was a presumptuous statement to say I know practically nothing about seizures.

I'm a Paramedic. I think they need to offer classes that teach the public not to stand around at the scene of a person who's having seizure activity and ask stupid questions like "Does he want fries with that shake."
A person can die in a seizure. That's a fact. Seizure activity, as our captain says, is nothing to clown around about.
I get tired of people doing that. I'm not a saint. I'm an Emergency Medical Technician at the Paramedic level.
I wish there were more classes that explain how serious seizure activity really is. Sometimes, I think some people NEED to feel the import behind the words. Their comfort or discomfort at know what it's really like shouldn't matter as much as getting the point through their heads.

Epilepsy, has been in our family  for 18 yrs Chaz has had  seizes started at the age of 4 yrs. he has the grandma seizes.  It is so hard. For me when he goes into a seizes ,  it is so hard to be there and I can't  do anything for him ,I pray and I  talk to God to help me and Chaz  get through this seizes ,I. Feel so helpless.,and sad for Chaz  for what he is going through . The seizes are so hard on him,I. Couldn't make it all these years with. Out Gods love and his blessing. It is a shame that people  don't understand  how hard it is for Chaz  to get through a day without having a seizes and all the medication he has to take. People look at him  as being different ,afraid  of him , I don't know why !!  He loves people wants to be around people and other kids. We love Chaz so very much . Thanks for taking time to read this ,I needed to write  this and to let everyone know your not alone  out there ,iand if when your feeling  sad and down remember  I'm praying for all of you  and I feel your pain too.

THANK GOD I HAVE BEEN FREE FROM SEIZURES FOR 4 YRS.  BECAUSE OF GETTING THE RIGHT MEDICATION AND CORRECT DOSAGE...
Mine does deliver every day but week ends. I have a great pharmacy. Although I have not a seizure for 22 years they know how I can not miss one dose.

Even though we take our meds. Every day it doesnt work in preventing a siezure! I wish every one would understand this . Trust me, like i would like the results from not taking my meds, really people .

I get my daughters filled at target, they are wonderful. They do not deliver but me or a family member could pick it up. I keep my daughters meds a makeup bag, that serves as a medicine bag. Inside, I have index cards with AM and PM meds directions, dosages. I also have an index card with on call neurologist, her pediatrician and her insurance information. It's useful when she stays at a family member or friends. It keeps it all organized too!  :-)
Beverly- I wish I was u on so many levels. Idk of a pharmacy that delivers (I live in Chicago-you would think they would) & to be seizure free. God bless you hun!

NOW...she has had these FOUR episodes in FOUR WEEKS. After the 3rd we were finally able to meet with a neurologist and medication was prescribed yesterday. Today she had another seizure. WHAT IS GOING ON?!?!? How does she go from never having one to having them so frequently?!?!?

I want to wish you all the luck in the world with your test and that you will be a candiate forr the surgery. I had the surgery back in 2011 and I am now seizure free amoung other things I now have.. Surgery was the best thing in the world you could ever imingine to have done. There needs to be more awareness of what this illness is. It is totally treatable! There should be more education in the schools. Teachers do not have modern knowledge of what to do should a child have a seizure.
BTW - There was a time in history when a person stricken with epilepsy was considered lucky because they were chosen by the gods to receive special knowledge from them during their spells!
And did you know in the 40's they viewed it as a sign of mental illness? My mother was institutionalized at 10 for having seizures. And her mother allowed it. Very sad existense.

This way of thinking still exists in the area we live. They believe it is demons and punishment for something the family has done wrong. I have unfortunately been told this to my face about my 11 year old son. IGNORANCE!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Is so sad how  we get lable... If they only understood.. GOD KNOWS

I'm doing an interview for the blog Robert's sister, wearing awareness buttons, and a hat that says "I have Epilepsy. What's Your Problem?"
How many readers REALLY know what Epilepsy is?
I do my granddaughter age 11 has it, I have been posting the awareness pics on also, lets keep it going, esp with 50,00 ppl die from it and effects of it every year!
Is there a Walk planned?
Every epileptic and family , frienfs place epileptic awareness on facebook every moment through out the day !!! Nov. PURPLE WE STAND TALL NOT FALL
please do all you can this is a very serious and can deadly illness I have it so thats why I'm so adiment on it

i struggle with a 5year old everyday and she was diagnosed @ 2. I pray for healing but educate myself as much as possible. We will be making ribbons for school church and loved ones to spread THE word!
i have epilepsy as well and we definitely should do all we can to help spread the word we need to make ribbons, sings whatever
and we need to help incourge one another
Wear those ribbons!  Make folks ask what it is for...that's awareness.  Take a stand to get our government involved in more funding for epilepsy.  http://www.epilepsyadvocate.com for more info

This page is for friends of Epilepsy Advocate to discuss their concerns and share support and encouragement for each other. Please make sure your posts align with the philosophy of our page. If you are unsure about what you can post, check out our community guidelines. Thanks.
I have a grand daughter who is 14 and has epilepsy
who/what does that refer to?
hosting a house concert to benefit the southern wisconsin epilepsy foundation
I will start spreading the news about seizure alert dogs from Canine support teams inc.
will do !!!!!
I will having a photo contest on my page Sparkle & Shine and giving away a custom made tutu dress to help raise awareness. I am a mom of 2 boys with epilepsy.
Way to get in there and advocate for this! So happy you are involved. You won't regret it. HUGS
This is very special for EpILIPTICS WORLD WILD  ,, SUPPORT
So tired of dealing with this "disease." No meds work, no insurance...whatever
i have it and glad they have an awareness month help those that are suffering with epilepsy
I have t.c. but have been seizure free for 7 yrs. I will go to read about e as much as I can n share it. There r some people who think that people with e are not smart n other things.
I spead the work Every Day and Especially in November!
I have to talk about it because I have Epilepsy
IM HAVE ALL 4 TYPES OF EPILEPSY SINCE I WAS 2 MONTHS OLD
Trying to put the finishing touches on my plans for the month
I will be wearing purple!
make the football payers wear purle they wore it for breastcance awareness, so how about for epilepsy awareness also.
I'm epileptic and my dentist was actually asking me if i could find help some how with repairing my teeth due too the grinding that happens during my seizures
Kathy I am here for you if there is anything I can do to help.  I will help you get the word out.
Prayer...
amen..
Lots of prayer!
good tips
Lots of prayer
Prayers & faith. I also make sure I take 5 or 10 mins for myself each day.

Sleep when she sleeps, find friend/family to chit chat about life/world events/etc with during those few free moments to help you reconnect with rest of world, sit on porch swing and relax a few minutes while she watches her favorite shows just a few feet away, use those few minutes when she's in someone else's care (school) to get things done that have to be done, and then use whatever time is left (if any) to do little things for me (plant flowers is one of my favorites (when I do get a chance to sit in porch and gaze in flowers, they remind me that God is at work in this world and has a plan for everyone), but it can take a long time to actually have time to plant) ...  Just little things here and there to help maintain the sanity and offload some of the stress.

I crochet alot, I make several items for charity, I make time by doing my own pedi and mani, and  I do genealogy research. In between making sure my husband is ok. Hes had epilepsy for years, so we have most of his triggers figured out, we try to talk to others  with epilepsy who need guidance, research, and a friend to talk to as well.  Its good to live as much of your own life as possible, when possible. Ane yes daily prayers are in our own lives as well. We  pray every night before bed time and we take turns. Its good to take a few minutes, if you cannot do more.  God bless you all.

Between being a caregiver & my 2 children at home....I have NO time for me. Im having surgery Nov.1 & the time I get off after(of coarse unpaid) will be the time I et to take care of me. Other than that....forget about it!!

Caregivers are on call 24-7 at least at my house. I make a little me time every day. Take a walk or bake something to share. Explore new recipes. Connect with friends. Go out every Wednesday to my weight watcher meeting enjoying my me time makes me a better wife daughter mom.

I am not a caregiver, I am one of the unfortunate ones that needs the care.   What I would suggest is that if you are taking care of someone with epilepsy,  try and talk with them and learn all you can about the deises, and remember to be pateint with the person that suffers from it
Laughter. A small joke goes a long way. :)
Take some time to meditate.........along with prayers of thanks....don't repeat your prayers rather say thank you for moving them so quickly and always on time:)
My husband and I take turns going to the gym, and spending with great friends.

You have to be strong and embrace it. God wouldn't have given you this responsibility if you couldn't handle it. Your loved one needs you. It is difficult and seems unfair at times, try and enjoy the times that are seizure free and try for your loved one to live as much of a normal life as possible while maintaining their safety. It's definitely a hard balance!

crying. i have to let it out somehow. so i sit on front porcha t night snuggled in my blanket with my favorite teddy. even at 39 i still love my bear. after the crying them i find some laughter. i epilepsy is hard but sometimes he does silly and funny things with some of his confustion. one day i came home to froot loops lined up in colors on the sofa. he didnt remember doing that but after the concern goes away it is funny.
I take a half day from work and go to the spa, it really helps. I also learned reiki which has helped my healing and his.
Id like that
we'd like that....LOL

from_name: Embracing Change, Accepting a Brain Injury and Living with Epilepsy
message: I love this magazine!!!
Link doesn't work

Hi, Marah Lee Johnson. We apologize for the inconvenience. Try loading the page again, and if the problem persists, please let Facebook know by visiting http://www.facebook.com/help/?page=272190606150902. Thanks for your help!
see? Alot of people think that epileptics cant do much-well look at Vincent Van Gogh
I just hope I don't end up cutting my ear off.
Vincent no one appreciated him until he was gone how sad know one bought a painting until he was gone :-(  starry night how beautiful
Really I did not know he had seizures
So people think we're not smart but Epiletics in cases are smarter than most people!
from my understanding, Van Gogh ate paint chips that gave hime the seizures and made him mad.
I heard Neil Young has seizures too. Look at him, great singer and songwriter
Many famous people had epilepsy!
That is a cool fact to know! My husband is an artist and my son has seizures so it is neat to know that they both can relate to someone as amazing as Vincent van Gogh
To me as an epileptic I've come to understand that certain things i may not be able to do but on the flip side i adapted and got better at other things.
I'm going to try to get a speaker from the epilepsy foundation of Louisiana to come speak to our school, and I'm problay going to make purple wrist bands
Would love something in my area
My brother had epilepsy and I will always be an advocate for those suffering- Jesus is the Great Physician!
Because of society's gnorance, too many epileptics suffer in silence.  Get educated, then help make a difference!
*ignorance

my son has epilpsy he get two tpye of  he get fogal & epilepsy it is the most scary thing I want to join u'r team and learn more my family & I are learning how to cope with this because my son is the youngest of all 6 of my children so we always  watching him and aware of his surronding at all time

fianally have a good neurologist. I'm in the process of changing meds and boy is it a stinker. I'm one who has been very careful about who I tell. it wasn't so very long ago that they institutionalized us and before that we were burned as witches. some things have changed but  not enough. Looking forward to Novemeber to see all the cool things you have planned.
I agree,and be careful with the new meds, Some can do more damage than good! I know been going through this for 47yrs. Back in the hospital on the29th on this month!
I wish I could get my epilepsy awareness tattoo nex month instead of having to wait until February *still 17
I  am 51yrs old  and i wish i could o to these gathering that you have for the epliepsy that you have for us but i just cannot afford it
