For information about epilepsy awareness in your area, or to join local support groups visit http://www.epilepsyfoundation.org/getinvolved/
Koool i just can't wait !!
I am an epileptic who is on of the lucky ones. I have not had a seizure since 1978! I hope there will be a cure someday cause it is very difficult disease and society needs to change their views
i was wondering if you are going to do anything in michigan cause i live in michigan and want to more about epilepsy because me and my mom have epipilepsy and i'm only 13 but i wont to help.
my father has epilepsy but its controlled for years with meds
Let me know my husband has epilepsy controlled with meds I also have a sister with work with children don't know if I can do anything maybe my husband can help write me on face book about group Maura
Where are you located I am in psl.
I have question. I have been applying for Certified Nursing Assistant Jobs, can they ask you if you have a disability on the app.?

Sorry, Amanda, but due to certain restrictions we can’t answer your question here. You may be able to find the answers you need at epilepsy.com or epilepsyfoundation.org.* Thanks for commenting!

Hi Lizzy Dougherty, Love the enthusiasm! There are plenty of ways to get involved right away. For ideas, visit http://www.epilepsyadvocate.com to find out how our Epilepsy Advocates are getting involved. And remember, you don’t have to be an official Epilepsy Advocate to make a difference.
how do you become a friend of epilepsy advocate?  i signed up several months ago but have yet to receive any information or the magazine.  ould you please help me out.  thank you.

For information about epilepsy awareness in your area, or to join local support groups visit http://www.epilepsyfoundation.org/getinvolved/
I was so proud and thankful to know all of that Kathy. You are a real trooper.
isnt that awful but all the named diseases get more attention than epilepsy!
Sad:( And no one understands epilepsy.
how welll I know DEbi...to well  :-(
Me too

and about 70% of those with epilepsy have intractable(I am pretty sure this is the right word) epilepsy which means that no matter what all meds and even brain surgery have been done still have seizures- I am one of those people
I am sorry. Knock on wood I havent had a seizure since 1978!
wow you have gone through alot. I would be TIRED and FRUSTRATED!
I hate havin seizures
My best friend has two children with it and I pray for them every day. I want to do more but she lives far from me.
Hate this,
people need to be informed and not scared of us, what we can do

I hate when instead of asking me about my Epilepsy, some people act like it's like catchable.  Even with my meds I still have seizures.  Very frustrating, but it's part of my life so I accept it.  Just wish more seizure free people were informed, and could accept it.  Instead, of apparently scared.

My 8 year old has epilepsy and because the kids are not properly educated on it they make fun of her and don't want to be her friend because of fear she may have one. IT's crazy and there needs to be as much awareness on epilepsy as there is on cancer and aids
I've had my share of grand mal siezures, dont wish them on anyone !!!!!

After being diagnosed 35 yrs. ago, I can in all honesty say I really could have done without all the seizures. It took almost 30 yrs. to find the right "cocktail" (as I like to call it ) of meds to control them for the most part.  The one misconception I really can't stand being asked by people " Are you contagious? " REALLY!!!!! It's a neurological disorder, not a freaking STD! People need to be better educated about seizures and the first aid for them.

Juanita, You are in the right place. If you are interested in getting involved, just check out our events tab or visit http://www.epilepsyadvocate.com to find some great ideas so you can help spread awareness for epilepsy.
No I did not know that ...  but being Epileptic I feel like I have a rather large family now!

Yea i did i have epilepsy since i was 8 years old my last siezure was @ 24 yrs.old the birth of my son well know i am 44 yrs.old and it came back now im back having them again,and the docs.cnt dnt know whynow i cnt work no more due to this i can deal wth the seizure but i cnt deal wth when i have them i sleep for 2 days and the meds arent working!!!Not sure what they will do next!im the only that has this my children didnt get thank god!
I'm a veteran of "it". 34 years and going strong.
I just say I'm parked diagonally in a parallel universe.
It's a question for a fool's errand. But if you feel a seizure about to happen, is there a way to prevent/avoid it?

Michael, this sounds like something you may want to discuss with your doctor. If you're looking for an epilepsy specialist, this site might be useful to help you find one: http://www.aesnet.org/go/find-a-dr                                    *UCB does not endorse and is not responsible for the content on a website not sponsored by UCB.

Agreed, Love this Pic!!!!!!
my kids needs one
going for the WIN!!!
not ashamed of having
Always Winning.

We are CHAMPIONS. Conquering Health Actions Moving Proudly Involved Our Nasty Situations. CHAMPIONS
I'm a Survivor of the seizure going strong. YAHOWAH bless Me.

from_name: Embracing Change, Accepting a Brain Injury and Living with Epilepsy
message: Loved this! Thanks for sharing!
You rock Melissa!
Thanks, everyone! :)
I suffer from Epilepsy and it's no joke.  I did 2 college papers on it, only to educate people on epilepsy

I also, and  am trying to decide how to celebrate control of my seizures for the 1st time since 1980 !!!  I have had a great year <3  Am open to ideas, please share even how you celebrate the small successes :)
I've earned these scars
I've learned from these scar, but never forget. Each day i wonder.

I truly would appreciate any information or suggestion to help our 24 year old son. We found out a few months ago that he has epilepsy.  He was told he cannot be a firefighter anymore, cannot drive, etc. I am at a loss sometimes as to what to say. I try to be encouraging, and positive, since I am a heart attack survivor.  I wish the best for all of you and hope you all have a blessed day.
Actually Dee, there are plenty of epilepsy resources available on Epilepsy Advocate’s website at http://www.epilepsyadvocate.com/resources/epilepsy-programs.aspx. Have a look.

Dee i am 34 on nov 6th. my first grand Mal seizure was when i was 3. i  had my first seizure on my third b-day. i also have an 11 year-old daughter with epilepsy. it is very discourging to be someone that has to live with this disease. your son is more unfortunate than me. give him some time to grieve the losses that he has had to go through with this. i wanted to be a chef. they told me no because of the heat. i will pray.  he has lost alot of privliges that other people take for granted. i know how he feels in some aspects. i gave my daughter to my mom because of my seizures onfornately all i can say is it is a hard disease and you and him will learn to live with it. get him to go to places with you show him that he is normal like everyone else like you have been. it is hard i know but it sounds like you have been doing a great job. he may not see this as a normal part of life for awhile so just tell him hey i am here. i love you. i am your mom. tell him this is just an obstacle and he is a very strong man.
Sarah, sounds like a good group!  You are a very amazing and brave lady, and I love you!  What would your 4 words be??  xo
That is so true,,,,,,,,,,,,,,

Do they have these at a professional level? As in first responders? Or is it community based events?
I'm a Paramedic, but I don't remember liking this page. But since I already have, I'm wondering about it. B/c there are seizures of several types but not all of them are considered epileptic. Like febrile seizures for example.

Completely off topic but I couldn't find another place to ask this. But are there any events coming up anywhere near lima Ohio. It's okay if it's a little further but I want to do something for the cause. Please inbox message me if you know

Epilespy ! I thimk i had a seizure lst night, picked myself off the floor, eye brow has a pump. Didnt bite my tongue , bad head ache and kindda out of it this morning ? A life of a epilelptic , really?
Sharon, are you making fun? I REALLY want to know.
Thank-You Hank
Vicki, Excellent question. We will try to get back to you as soon as possible with an answer on that.

Hi there, Cori. We do our best to post as many events as we can. If you don’t see any listed for your area, try contacting your nearest Epilepsy Foundation Affiliate*. They may know of some events we haven’t heard about yet! Find them here: http://www.epilepsyfoundation.org/aboutus/Find-an-Affiliate.cfm
My 3 year old was just diagnosed with epilepsy she has tonic clonic & absence
now i know.  thanks eric
Me too, thanks
what is it's title?
No I didn't know but I do now.
yes i did
Did you know that Beethoven also had Epilepsy besides being deaf.
Not surprising, Julius Caesar has epilepsy as well.
I count out two weeks' worth and put them in a different room.  When the current bottle gets low, I move the current bottle to the kitchen so I have to keep reminding myself to refill it.
I wish my daughters doctors would get hers under control and keep it that way.

I have it on my calendar the very first day I can reorder it . I call them that day or very soon and reorder. I also have a weeks worth in my purse with a piece of paper with my doctors , their phone numbers, the medicines, the doses , the mg, and my medical illnesses. Everyone I love knows I have that so if I have to go to the hospital they won't have to jump through hoops to get that information. Plus it comes in handy with all those pesky doctors appointments.
yes
absolutely!

I filled my daughter's medication and then had her doctor write a 90 day prescription through her insurance company.  At any given time I have a 30 to 120 days of her medication on hand.  The medication coming in a 90 day supply is cheaper than going month to month through a local pharmacy.  I also use my flexible spending account to pay for all her medications that many do no take advantage of through their jobs.  As soon as the 90 day prescription arrives I send in the reorder form and they auto fill it on the first day it is eligible to fill.  This is one of my greatest fears is to be without her medication.
Joy, I do TH 90 day supply too.  I have had Epilepsy for 43 years.  Better safe than sorry.  When I pack for a trip, my medicine is packed 1st.  It is the most important item.
I also have at least 90 day supply on hand...alwady keep some at home & in my purse in case i feel i need a little extra.
I know that a lot of companies  offer flex spending accounts.  You can estimate what your yearly cost of medications and place the money in that account and reduce your taxable .income
I have a plan, have about a weeks worth of pills that I F.I.F.O. each month. it was well worth the little extra money.
not very good at this...
Very necessary
Have always made sure that I have a week supply on hand.  HAVE NEVER EVER gone without.
Let me tell you its scary as hick knowing you may run out, for i know what WILL HAPPEN.
yes I make sure I have enough!
Our insurance will only cover 30 days at a time so we usually get a vacation advance once a year which gives us a little buffer.  Wish we could get 90 days at a time...but it's too expensive.
Can be a hassle but what is worse the medicine or the seizures?
food for thought and stuff to remember.
..  Written by PamJHWitcher - Always 'call' the Pharmacy when I have 1 to 1 1/2 weeks left. I am going to check on the 2 weeks.

A pill box is a great thing to have.  For those of us who are so forgetful it is a wonderful reminder.  Many times in the late morning hours I say to myself did I take my meds this morning? At that time all I need to do is go to my pill box and double check that I indeed took my medicine.  I agree with Randy another thing I do when I pick up my prescriptions is to ask the pharmacist if my meds are still in automatic refill, this comes in very handy.
Rebecca, what is it you don't want to do?  Take your meds or use a pill box?
i never have any extra. my insurance doesnt allow me to have any extra.
HELP!  my 25 yr. old son no longer has RX coverage.  Does anyone know of a program to help him get his seizure meds?????
other than medi-cal not really
I love it
be happy
" I won't give up!"
We can do ANYTHING!!!
positive attitude is key!
Millions need help adapting!
'I am worth it' :)
Lift your head up
Help
God is in control!
GRATE. Sign. Two thumb's UP
Taking TIME to adape!!!!!!!!!
Had a seizure lastnite, but keeping the faith....
I AM IN CONTROL!!
Wont keep me down!
had 3 seizures last week but i have faith that i will be in control... patience is key! the time will come :) keep smiling!
my son has alot of seizure's has had them for 35yr's not a easy thing to watch
Stay positive and trust GOD. It is a journey but you are not here for nothing.

God is able.  Three words, but true.  After 2 years of severe uncontrolled complex partials I had a right temporal lobectomy just over 4 years ago I am now back in college to pursue my dream.  3 years ago I thought my life was done.  God is able to do immeasurably more then I can ask or imagine!

I'm 27 and have had uncontroled epilepsy. since I was 8 months old the only thing I can say is you need to think possitive and doint worry about what others think of you just go threw life with a possitive attitude even whin things are challenging
and whin things get diffecult doint stop and think what life I have stop and think what life can you build doint hesitate. to set goals for yourself
Love For My Grandchild
My four (4)words that motivate me 2 go beyond the boundaries of my condition R 'yes I can do'

My precious son Dorian...He has to take such a high dose of meds that he doesn't know when I am near and the sad thing about it, they won't give him Disability Insurance, he can't drive, he can't work, he needs so much, and the state of California won't give him what he needs. I know of people who have faked illnesses and receive aid. Wow
You can do
All things through Christ!!
I always have a positive attitude on life because, having seizures since the age of 6 month has never held me back from my future dreams.
EPILEPSY WON"T STOP ME!!!!!!!!!!
.. stay positive about yourself .. Written By PamJHarfordWitcher
IT WON'T BEAT ME!!!
It will be cured
Where can I get more information on the "Walk For Epilepsy"?
Please read on my time line Stats for Epilepsy, thank you for caring
I know this very well!
I love it and so true
So very true!!
no pain no gain
Im always telling my daughter "You have Epilepsy, BUT Epilepsy does NOT have you!!!
where do I go to see the story???
God Bless U All, my prayers R with U.
It is on the poster. @marie
it won't stop Me!!!
...good for you!

So true, so very true!!! Keep going, because you are proving to so many, including myself, that epilepsy is not the end of the world, it's just something that we have been diagnosed with but can totally live a normal life with!!! Great job!!!!
"Me First, Seizures Second"
Alive, Strong,Loved and Blessed...how i feel with support from family and friends!
love it

Does anyone know how to get a run/walk like this started. Richmond is a huge race city and they have races for EVERYTHING except for epilepsy and I want to be that advocate that raises awareness and I would love to be able to put on a race like this. Help please!
Its so very hard but true , keep smiling :-)
Awesome!!!

Even after having just had another episode,  I totally agree:  I am not someone who has and lives with epilepsy,  I am a person with epilepsy.  I live my life like everyone else.  I will not let epilepsy define me!!

Thanks for you comment, Shana Rowlett. We recommend contacting your local chapter of the Epilepsy Foundation for information and assistance with planning an event. Search for a nearby affiliate here*: http://www.epilepsyfoundation.org/aboutus/Find-an-Affiliate.cfm

*UCB does not endorse and is not responsible for the content on a website not sponsored by UCB.

This just made my day. After getting home from work I find myself and my wife on the epilepsy advocate page. Everyone's comments did more for me today than anyone could imagine, not because they were directed at me but because it meant that other people understand. That amazing woman next to me helped me believe in those four words on the poster and I thank God for her.
Very cool
Dogs
congrats Weston that is wonderful.  I hope you continue to be seizure free.  I am going to look into that supplement.  Thanks
Siezures change everything in your life..  I struck 3 pedestrians in a cross walk (thank GOD they are ok) but no driving, no work, no disability.. All I can say is that I'm happy to be alive!
i know bc i have them but they dont rule my life. :))
I have been diagnosed with complex partiel seizures for over 25 years and I continue to learn about epilepsy. Support anyone you know that has it, they will greatly appreciate it.

My daughter has gran mal seizures.  She had two last night.  I am spreading awareness of this horrible and scarey disorder.  People don't understand the real dangers for anyone who has any kind of seizures.

My son had a near fatal car accident back in March due to a partial onset seizure. He had been seizure free for almost a year. I am grateful he did not hurt anyone and he is alive. It has taken him six months to learn to walk again. No driving for now - license was revoked but he is o.k. with that for now until he has this fully under control. He is being evaluated for a second brain surgery.
I am an epileptic and I truly know the dangers, thank you for educating everyone

I have one friend who can look at me and know something is going to happen soon or something isn't right. I dont drive. Love her sooo much. People think if they can't see a disability it isn't there.I am lucky I have wonderful friends and a really great family. Love them so much!! I have had the same job for 25 years and they have been good to me also.  I am a lucky one. I love life.
My daughter has absence and partial seizures. Knowledge and support are very powerful. Prayers for continuing advances in treatments.
Try having a grand mal siezure /on the floor like a fish,biting tongue, bleeding , hopefully didn't hit or enjury myself or anyone, sore for day depending on situation and a hole lot more , etc
I've had 2 major accidents(not knowing what they were) after many years of meds.and other injuries, finally had surgery to stop them.thank God for surgery!

I had grandmal and petit mal seizures from the time I was 4 until I was in my 30's.  Then suddenly they stopped.  I haven't had any kind of seizure since 2002.  I am almost 41 now and by the grace of God, I haven't had any seizures, and also no medication.  I know the seriousness of this first hand.

I used to walk alot but one day went to cross the road and if a friend had not been with me I wouldn't be here now because I had an absence seizure and didn't know I was crossing the road when a car or two was coming. Yes they are dangerous as well but you learn to cope.
the dangers with partial /complex seizures is they dont show activity alot of the times on an eeg,as why there were 2 car accidents becuse nothing showed up on the eeg after the first accient

You know what is more to seizures? People think you are weird and when you cant hold or find a job you are broke all the time.and what is  worse they tell you how they hate you being broke all the time.
Let me add to this and after you have been told your entire life you are nothing but worthless you start to believe it and end up getting nowhere.
Thankyou Epilepsy Advocate for all that you share, Alot of people just didnt know.

Been through this :/ I was driving n had a seizure.  Later I found out that I crossed 4 lanes including upcoming traffic.  My vehicle went over into private parking lot.  It hit four vehicles,  plus hit the ceramic garbage can (crashed it ), broke the enterance door of private business.  Thanks God, nobody died.  I didnt drive independetly after that.  Two years ago, had a brain surgery in Rush Hospital,  Chicago n I am a seizures FREE.
My heart and prayers go out to you Theresa.

been through this and more; it has its moments. Ive lately been through Cleve clinic (OF OHIO)  for their Monitor unit for epilepsy; keep me in thoughts and prayers aas Im going through more tests and then possible surgury
praying......God can heal!!!

I've had epilepsy for 17.5 years now. Finally a doctor found a good mix of pills for me to take. I have Grand Mal siezures, Complex Partial Siezures and Simple siezures. I've never driven a car, never had a girlfriend, never been to a bar, So many things. I haven't done. Regualar people don't know what seizures are. I started having them when I was 10. Now I have a V.N.S. (Vegus Nerve Stimulator) to help me stop some of the seizures but still most of the siezures come on to quick for me you use it.
I was in my senior yr of HS when a doctor finally believed us that something wasn't right. I have 3 different types of seizures, the majority being absence. It changed my life, for the good and bad.

I have complex partial seizures, mostly in the middle of the night, which affects my sleep. If I feel weird, I don't drive. i think this happens to me especially since my siezures are induced by stress

They grabbed the wheel. My Dr. revoked my license and put me in new meds.. All is good now!`` =)

My daughter's seizures are all generalized, rather than partial, but I can attest to the fact of how scary Epilepsy can be! Well I don't know what causes epilepsy but it is disturbing,  I had another episode a couple of days ago. I was born with this dreaded illness and all I can say is I wish there was something I could do to stop getting them.   There are a lot of things I am no longer able to do, for example: drive, drink when I go out with friends and now another must a low sodium diet.  What causes these episodes?  I'd like to know.
Well mal just learned my daughter has pettie mal ones real scary for me noot knowing anything

Tonic Clonic seizures are painful and scary, I have found that most people are supportive when I have these. The most difficult for me are partial seizures.  Blanking out for a few seconds during a conversation, staring off into space, or certain odd uncontrollable body movements.  With these seizures I have found people aren't as supportive or understanding.  I don't have issues with people that do not know me.  What I have issues with and what really stings are the friends and family that do know.  Many make snide, low brow comments like "look at me when I'm talking to you," snapping their fingers in you face, treating you like an idiot, rolling their eyes when you talk or just plain being mean and rude.  I understand that it is ignorance and education is needed.  However, just as ignorance of the law is an invalid excuse for breaking it, treating others poorly and claiming ignorance is inexcusable as well.
I have been living with Epilepsy for 14 years now, and they still haven't gone away, an I have had two surgeries. I'm praying that I won't live with this problem for the rest of my life.

FOR me, it means being able to function like a "normal" human being (able to use the bathroom without assistance, take a shower by myself, not have to have someone stand by me when I stand up and walk around because there's a really good chance that I might fall over).  It means being able to sleep in my bed without worrying about falling out of bed and injuring myself or anyone around me.  This is seizure control to me.  I know it is very different for other people.  There's more to it than just this, but this is a start for me and I enjoy being able to at least do these simple things for once!

Vickie, A Pre-Existing Condition Insurance Plan (PCIP) provides new coverage options to individuals who have been uninsured for at least six months because of a pre-existing condition. States have the option of running this new program in their state. If a state has chosen not to do so, a plan should already have been established by the Department of Health and Human Services in that state. This program serves as a bridge to 2014, when all discrimination against pre-existing conditions will be prohibited.

That was one of the first things I found out while reading Encyclopedia Brittanica back in the 70's, when I first found out I had epilepsy. It stuck in my head all through my travels, as I hitched and walked across America so many times. If someone could be the ruler of an Empire and yet have seizures, why, then why, couldn't I do what I wanted to do in this world, especially since it is now a free-thinking world, where one does not have to do as their emperor says, or be fed to the lions. I would do just what I did do. Trek my way across this country, and show the common people of America that I, as an epileptic, am just as able to do as much, if not more than others. At first, I kept my seizures a private secret, until co-workers got to know & trust me, which was when I would then let them know about them. That way, if anything was to happen, be it at work or somewhere in their presence, they would know why I was acting different, and not to worry.

Also during my time across the country, I would discuss epilepsy with people off the street, or others who I got rides from, just to see their reaction, and to familiarize them with the misinterepretations many people have about epilepsy. It was educational for myself and them.

I am 27 yrs old and have lived with Epilepsy since I was about 15months old.  I have been on just about every drug out there and have lived anything but a normal life.  I did everything I could to live with it and try to not let it interrupt my life too much.  I was a very loyal and accountable employee until finally it took over my life.  I never called in sick unless I had to go to the ER because I couldn't function without having a seizure.  Finally I went to a new dr. earlier this year and was introduced to something called VNS.  I had this implant put in back in March.  It has made a tremendous difference in my quality of life!  I can actually go to sleep and not be so concerned about having horrible seizures in my sleep or wake up having them.  I'm not cured, but I definitely have a better quality of life!  Thanks to everyone involved in making this possible!  One thing that is essential in having Epilepsy, even as an adult is having a good support system and someone around to help you almost at all times.  I have never been able to live on my own because of this.

As you may know, epilepsy is a complicated condition. That’s why we are working hard to get the information out there. We appreciate your comment and try to keep in mind that anyone with epilepsy should consult their doctor before making any lifestyle changes.

What happened to the story? Well my dream was to become a therapeutic riding instructor. I was taking therapeutic riding lessons, while having seizures at age 17. I did that, and more!!!:) Now, my dream is to ride horses, more and open a therapeutic riding facility.

My dream is to become a nurse. I had my first seizure when I was 1. I had a "break" after 3 years, and my seizures stopped, but came back when I turned 12. Ever since, I struggled to get diagnosed. I had my first seizure when I was 8.  Very little was known about epilepsy then (1953) and a little later my folks were told they should put me in an - insane is not the word but close to it - asylum. Working for most of it and  married 41 years this Oct.   They are now controlled and I haven't had a seizure in about 6 years.

My daughter began experiencing seizures at 3 months old. Nobody believed me, at first, that anything was going on because they were so short and infrequent. I knew. I just knew.For years I dealt with it without any kind of diagnosis and everyone thinking I was being overly cautious and making a big deal out of nothing. She started preschool and the teacher would send home discipline notes every day about how she wouldn't listen. How she spent too much time daydreaming. About how she was defiant and would sit and stare at her desk instead of lining up with the other kids.. I told them what I had suspected since she was an infant. They didn't believe me. I told her doctor. She said "Sometimes kids just daydream.."  At seven, she complained on New Years Day of a headache.. Then, her seizure started. I drove through a blizzard to get her to the emergency room and the seizure was still taking place. They finally believed me. She is now 8. Her seizures are for the most part under control. She's beginning hippotherapy this week. 

Nobody knows better than a mother. If you feel that your child needs something, fight for it. All too often serious matters are disregarded as behavior issues when, in fact, they actually have no control over it. Don't give up.

I was born with it myself. After having home through 2 surgeries. I'm happy to say I haven't. Had a seizure in 4 1/2 yrs.
The first surgery was a temporalobectomy. It slowed them down a lot. I went from having 12-15 per month to 1-2 every 6 months.
My doctors still weren't satisfied. I was on large amounts of medications.  On march 17,2008 my doctors put in a NVS Vagus Nerve Stimulator. Since I had the implant put in I haven't had any seizures. They were also. Able to cut back on my medications.
I will probably always have to take some meds but not as much. ;-)

i tell others that epilepsy does not run my life, i will not burst out in a seizure, i am not a ticking time bomb, i am not contagious. If you have questions, ask! i'll let you know if i don't want to answer :) Talking about it and putting out in the open dispels a lot of myths and misconceptions.

Become an advocate in your area.  Take advantage of local festivals to hand out brochures, teach seizure first aid, and offer a listening ear with an open heart.  Epilepsy advocacy is simply loving other people who have epilepsy by standing up for them, educating yourself and the public, sharing information especially updates in the local newspapers, making yourself available on radio talk shows and cyber networking, and enjoy not feeling alone by sponsoring an epilepsy "Family and Friends Day" picnics.  Any way you can spread a healthy word about epilepsy and help others who struggle with it,  It's a step in the right direction.   My ten year anniversaby as an epilepsy advocate is the the first week of July, just two months after brains surgery.  I'm not bragging just encouraging.  As the old saying goes, if it feels good do it.  Take my word for it when I say, epilepsy advocacy feels good.  Join me.

My best friend has epilepsy & so does my boyfriend...recently he had 5 seizures in the space of bout 5-6 min...he went to his doc & did a MRI...seems that he may have had a small stroke during that time...he has to have a sleep-deprived EEG soon...crossing my fingers that its not too serious...although it has taken him a long time to bounce back...doc wanted to put him on a mood-stabilizer but it will cause more problems...any suggestions?  Please le me know on my wall.....

I agree with you Chris...I have had to deal with epilepsy a a child and now as an adult..It is realy time to break down the stigma that people with epilepsy cannot be thereownperson...I myself am gettiing my BA in Health Care Administration at Ashford University Online.

For example, don't stick anything in a person's mouth while s/he is seizing.  Really, dad, a spoon? I'm lucky to still have my teeth.  He's still lucky to have his thumb, because that's what he was using prior to the spoon.  It is HIGHLY unlikely the person will bite off the tongue and swallow it.
Don't not freak out.  This to shall pass.
CHRIS IS SO RIGHT

Believe, support, hope together!  Continue to believe in a better epilepsy treatment tomorrow; support others who live with epilepsy by listening, encouraging & sharing what you know; and always speak up to inform & educate when you have the opportunity.
ACT. Follow my dreams because nothing can stop me. Epilepsy is just one part of who I am, it's not who I am.
DON'T BELIEVE ALL DOCTORS.

i tell others that epilepsy does not run my life, i will not burst out in a seizure, i am not a ticking time bomb, i am not contagious. If you have questions, ask! i'll let you know if i don't want to answer :) Talking about it and putting out in the open dispels a lot of myths and misconceptions.

Become an advocate in your area.  Take advantage of local festivals to hand out brochures, teach seizure first aid, and offer a listening ear with an open heart.  Epilepsy advocacy is simply loving other people who have epilepsy by standing up for them, educating yourself and the public, sharing information especially updates in the local newspapers, making yourself available on radio talk shows and cyber networking, and enjoy not feeling alone by sponsoring an epilepsy "Family and Friends Day" picnics.  Any way you can spread a healthy word about epilepsy and help others who struggle with it,  It's a step in the right direction.   My ten year anniversaby as an epilepsy advocate is the the first week of July, just two months after brains surgery.  I'm not bragging just encouraging.  As the old saying goes, if it feels good do it.  Take my word for it when I say, epilepsy advocacy feels good.  Join me.

Drs I've encountered so far that are suppose to be helping my best friend with his abnormal seizure activity just brush him off by changing meds. It's time to understand that each case of seizures is unique and needs to be researched in a way that doesn't break a patients bank account!
I  have had epilepsy for 14 years and enjoy telling my story of trials and tribulations!

I agree Courtney I have had it since I was 3 hours old and now I'm 25 and have over come a lot... Learning disability, speech problems, and I have a type of seizure that they believe to give me mood swings and I have learned how to control my angry and mood swing and we all should be damn proud of what we over come because many people would just give up and not even care

I agree with you. In a way I am glad to have epilepsy.  It has helped me learn a lot and a lot.  I have had it for over 40 years.  When I was young people would tell me I could not do something because I had seizures, this motivated me to show them I could do it.  I have been to college, I still live on my own, handle my own finances and can do more on my laptop tham my caseworker can.
Educate myself!  I cannot dispell the myth's if I don't know the info!

no, not usually a smile just a smpleasl s moving laterally

My grandfather had a dog with epilepsy.  We use to talk about the meds the dog took and the ones my daughter took, if they worked or not!!  Funny thing is, that if it didn't work for her it didn't work for the dog either and vice versa.

my sister-in-law's dog has seizures.  The first time I met the dog, it took to me instantly and hung around me all day.  She said her dog NEVER likes strangers, so I suppose it could sense that we were very similar!
I have epilepsy and have had 2 dogs with the same . It was very hard to see when Katie had lond seizures.
Idk if it is epilepsy, but I have seen my dog have a couple at random, they looked exactly the same too! It was scary.

It's incredibly hard to see a pet you love so much have seizures.  It's surreal, knowing your body contorts in that manner & heartbreaking as you wish you could have the seizure for them.  I miss my Marbles.  <3
I love my dog coley I hug her all the time ,take her to the park and eveing let her sleep with me when Mike is away lol.
I have it and my mom had a dog with it

A fundraiser or what?  I want to participate...
except it says "There are no upcoming events"
We have two do it evrey day as remind me I do I were my purple wrist band
If "optimal" control  means no seizures,the answer is no.    I wish it existed.

But I never have given HOPE that in my lifetime, my daughter will be 80% seizure free, thanks to my pushing to try new things for her.  My theory is "We have nothing to loss and everything to gain.  If it doesn't help her it might help someone else."
I am 50 years old, the siezures are hitting every few months and that is so much better than everyday. I can live with it.

If you feel like your doctor is not thinking outside the box, find another doctor. My daughter's doctors became stagnant and failed in running simple tests in finding a true diagnosis. Had my husband and I not gone to this other doctor we wouldn't have the answers we do now.
Yes I agree with you Laura Locklear Dubois I am like you but I have my meds under control now found a good doctor that has helped me control it

My daughters last doctor just loaded her up on all sorts of meds and never ran blood tests or anything I finally said that's enough and looked around and found a doctor that's more active in her treatment  he is trying new things new meds and running appropriate tests. I am so happy to cause the med we are taking her off of right now I never want her on again. She is almost completely off of it and her language and awareness has improved soooo much!
And she hasn't had any seizures while coming off of the med so in my opinion it was doing more harm than good

It took the 3rd neurologist to tell me I actually have epilepsy, not brain damage. It pointed out my frontal left lobe & says "this means you have epilepsy, period." The other docs told me I must of hit my head, hard on the right to have scare tissue on my left lobe. If you see your child isn't getting the proper care, don't settle, there are more knowledgeable docs out there :)

I appreciate my doctors efforts with my seizures, I try to push my doctor to try new meds, but my doctor and another doctor don't want to. They say that I'm fine with the meds I have now, Even though I still get seizures. It has taken over my life and it sucks

I've had many doctors since I was diagnosed with epilepsy and have gone thru so many meds, but I don't give up and I certainly don't let it get me down...I'll keep on fighting even if it means fighting with doctors! (which I've done in the past)
Absolutely !! Everyday
I went years and years on 4 seizure meds and no control. Since I had my vagus nerve stimulator put in I have dropped to two seizure meds and have gone 29 months seizure free!

As a Pediatric Neurology nurse, I read these comments, and want to do the very best I can to improve the lives of my patients and their families. Educate yourselves. Empower yourselves! Do not accept mediocrity. Ask for what you need. And I will listen, and try to help, to the best of my ability!

I've had epilepsy for 22 years and I don't know which changed more, my neurologist or my medications. I now have a great epileptologist who listens to me and that in my opinion makes him the best doctor near me.

23 years of uncontrolled seizures. More medications than I can remember, a cranial lobectomy, a VNS implant, and a new drug trial have not been successful. All I can do is hope. That's why I follow the latest research in epilepsy, support causes like The Epilepsy Foundation, and read sites like this. It also reminds me that I am not alone.
has anyone looked into Nora Gedgaudas ? she has had success with patients on a very specific diet. kids especially.

~WOW~ No wonder my head feels funny just before my seizures! Thanks for ALL the useful info!
Zzz_zzzzzzzzzzzzing!   Kapow!  Brrrrrrrring! Patcheouuuuu!

I have many different things that go on right before a seizure.  I have gotten a tingling sensation over one side of my head or down a leg.  I get a deja vu feeling when a seizure is just coming on.  scary. very scary!!!!!

I get weird twitches...especially in my temples.  I am semi aware until the twitches start.  Then it leads to a full tonic clonic.  If only that electricity could be used for superpowers, I would be set!
I never know. Always have them  at night time in my sleep. Wake up next day tired and exhausted with bite inside my mouth. No ryme or reason.Not fun.
I call myself Electric Girl! Looks like a serious short circuit! LOL. Also explains the headaches I usually have the morning of a seizure...getting ready for overdrive! Thanks for the info!
Must be why my head was spinning so fast the other day, when I had a seizure..get kind of dizzy.
as a parent, it is one of the hardest things I've ever seen my child go through...

If I get really dizzy and my head feels funny I lay down and sleep and sometimes it will go away and other times not. I too have seizures in my sleep because I will wake up finding I have bitten my tongue or the inside of my mouth.

Oh wow now i know why i be so dizzy when i wake up sometimes i have seizures in my sleep i will wake up bite inside my mouth too with blood yuck & i call myself  twitche girl lol cause i used to  twitche all the time then have full blown seizure very very scary now im medicine so i feel alot bettter Thank God
Thanks for sharing all the experiences and information. Watching your child have seizures is such a helpless feeling.

I think everyone with seizures  is a superhero and has super powers.  I don't know how many times I bit my tongue during a seizure or felt so dizzy, out of it, headaches, and so many other things. But I always somehow get through it. I think we all have super healing and super strength.  Because no matter how many times we fall, bite our tongues we can always heal. No mater how painful it is, scary, hard to deal with, the not knowing when its going to happen or why and many other thing's. We can all make it though and it dose take a superhero with super powers to do that.

I hate having seizures, I had them since I was 2yrs and I'm 26yrs. My mom has a short leash on me. Mine are uncontrolable, I don't know when I will have one, though mine can last for 5minutes or 6hrs, I take meds. Though, I've notice I only get'em when I'm stress,don't feel good or over-heated, just upset. I want to learn so badly, so I ask my doc if I can go back to school but on the net, he said yeah. But my mom thought I would get cut off SSI and my benifits, and so I had to cancel my app. I always wanted to take up web design. =/ so my life is boring.. all I do, is get up, take my meds and do whatever to keep me occupied. I have one friend that we go to places that we've too already, but she has a job so we hardly see eachother any more, and I really want to goto college online, make something of myself even though I can't work web-design would be awesome to learn by professional and i could make my own website, or help my mom..
I get daja vu and a pain in my left eye and the nerves twitch  Have 47yrs long time

Over the phone!! it was 1977 and I was working at a tee shirt graphics
shop and this guy called looking for someone who used to work there.
When he found out that she no longer worked there he all of a sudden
"came onto me"~"Well I guess I'm going to have to take you out to
lunch instead"~ On April 6th,we met for lunch and before I knew it
he went and proposed one Saturday afternoon!!!
We've just celebrated our 34 Anniversary,we married on 2-19-1978
He's wonderful when it comes to my Epilepsy,always making sure I
have my medications and he worries if I go anywhere alone.
My cell phone is really only for emergencies,not just calliing friends.
My husband & I met as a blind date. His best friend's girlfriend (now wife) was a mutual friend & thought we'd hit it off...we'll celebrate our 12th wedding anniversary this year! :)

We were in kindergarden together didnt know each other and later years where I was living he knew my neighbors then in our junior high school a friend called him and we talked and met the next day and been together ever since 30 something years. He is wonderful !!! :) God put us together!

Elizabeth Robles I met my husband in MySpace by one of my friends she  tells me to write to him I was a little scared to do it but finally I did write to him now he is the love of my love and I am going to celebrate my 2th year of my anniversary this year with the one I love <U+2764>
im not married but i met my boyfriend at church.....i offered him a piece of candy and by the end of our friendly conversation i had his number!!!!!!
I married my true love 3 years ago! We met through mutual friends and met at a horse ride. They had a party after the ride with a band and Bon fire! That is where I met my cowboy! Very happy!!!!!

I married my best friend 11 years ago but we actually met in seven grade! Amazing husband my support my everything! We are a team and I struggle we epilepsy and now one of my daughters too but we know that everything is possible and this condition is not going to control ours life:)

Met my hubby online.(Thank you Plenty of Fish.) About 4 months into dating I had a medication issue and had a HUGE Grand Mal in front of him.He took it in srtide, didn't run for the hills and still loved me as much afterwards. I already knew he was a keeper. But that clentched it.
I knew I had found true love when I had my first seizure on my future in-laws sofa. He got me to the hospital and stayed by my side for many trials with epilepsy.

When my husband I first started dating I had a grand mal in front of him, I was soooo embarrased.  After the siez. I told him that it was ok, he could leave, I'd understand, he looked and me and said "Do you see me going anywhere?"  He's been there ever since.
In high school....been with me for 38 years now, guess it didn't bother him.

I have spoken over and over with my Daughter Neurologist and we have even seen an epilepsy specialist but over the course of the last events since the beginning of the year they have gotten worse plus she has a VNS..
And I'm one of them...
My epilepsy pills give me depression ughhh! Thank God my Neurologist is takin me off of them.

My dad is 63 has epilepsy since 6yrs old went through every medication possible as he was a "guinea pig" has a VNS and Im happy to say my dad had a right temporal lobectomy march 30th..the surgeon had given him the percentage of 30% my father was having 5-6 seizures and 6-8 auras a month (sometimes less) and its been 6 weeks for either one.....
Yes I am one of them, frustrating
My son just had 2 on this saturday. Aggrivating when he is takinghis pills and still has them. With no tell we can never be sure.
I am one of them too : (
My son continues to have seizures, despite medication adjustments; his best seems to be periods where the activity is a few times each month. But overall, that's better!

I am stuck between a rock and a hard place where I cannot, due to side-effects, take all but one of the few meds that work for my types of seizures. Neither surgery nor VNS are options for me. I wish there weren't so many of us.
yes I did know...and yes I talked to my doctor...and because of our discussion I had L temporal lobectomy and have been seizure-free for 12 yrs as of tomorrow!!! Thank you Dr. Yeh!!!
It sucks, I had all the surgeries even vns implant, still haven't stopped yet

Never, never, never stop trying.  After 40 years of seizures, I am suddenly 3 years seizure free without surgery.  It just took the right combination of medication and VNS for me (plus a whole lot of patience, persistence, and determination!)
I do know that, infact I am one of those whose meds don't help, so I am having a Temporal Lobectomy in June.
Good advice, I think, Tomi!

Knowing what triggers my seizures, learning to stay away from triggers (if possible), and/or preparing myself for possible seizures at any time.
full body control...we wish
Control to us is when epilepsy is a part of our lives, it doesn't dictate our life.
@mary yes it does for my 13 year daughter when she has a  big test or drama in school is when I notice she has more ticks and jerks when she is asleep her happen when she falls a sleep

Amen Rebecca when my daughter had her first seizure it was crazy and my daughter was so upset when we found out she had epilepsy but we will not let this keep us down she will still be a teen girl and have fun ;)
Being able to remember the past few weeks & function as a normal person would....It had been over 1 1/2 years!!
control to me means not having 2 to 5 seizures a day with the medication Im on
Finding the right doctor and cocktail of meds to control me without making me a zombie!
We won't know what control is until we have it.

when my son doesn't have any more seizures and can live a happy normal life.  His biggest anxiety is having seizures in public places.  He hates it when people outside the family witness him having a seizure.
Getting to the point I can drive again. Add on another year after the seizure I had last week. :( And finding out WHY would be nice too.
no seizures period!

For me, stress brings my seizures on. I've had them for several years. Controlling mine consists of plenty of sleep, and for some reason a Pepsi. I heard a friend say it helps so i tried it. It worked for me for a little bit.
Seizure control means freedom to me

Seizure control to us is a non existant word. But...having better control means that our daughter is more alert and not seizing all the time and is happy!  As long as she is happy that is all that matters. God is in control as He has made sure that our daughter has a good quality of life. For that I thank her amazing Dr.
Lesser stress, taking breaks when necessary, and staying away from unhealthy substances that stimulate the brain.
Each person who has Epilepsy is different as night & Day.
No seizures ,driving, no fear,freedom
educating yourself and making sure u take every single dose no skipping

I like to call it "seizure management"!  Finding that fine line between sedation and seizure management for my 13 year old is hard.  She has at least 5 seizures per day now...we'll take it!  We've been status before and have dealt with lots more that 5 per day so we're happy with our "seizure management"!
take every dose of your medication-I got on the right 1 23 years ago,and it has been wonderful!
No meds, no restrictions  and no siezures.  That would be the only definition of true control for me.  In the meantime I guess it's life.
Taking meds (all 3 of them)making sure I sleep and my wonderful vagus nerve stimulator!  :D
No seizures at all!

Sleep, naps, no stress, no late night phone convos, set working schedule, no clamping jaw when trying to sleep, eat healthy, be a social drinker, exercise, take meds as prescribed :) All & one can help but I have nocturnal seizures.
@ Morphine...most good neurologists take payment plans, none of mine have turned me away, regardless of how much I owe!

If I try to handle my stress levels..and eat healthy on schedule..I can remain seizure free without medication! I just have to keep in mind I have epilepsy EVERYDAY and live with it and not against it! Over 5 years seizure free :)!! There have been times I have had to go back on meds but in the past 10 years I have come so far and I am so lucky!! To all of you still struggling..my wish is for all to find "control"!!
....if I ever had control, I would comment on what it means to me!

Comming to grips with the fact that for me, a seizure is possible and not the end of the world.  I'll gladyly take another than be on medication again!!  Sticking to my modified atkins diet and eliminating stress.  Telling families at the ED I work at to stop acting like thier patient is dying and stop embarassingly freek out around him/her.
FIND A PLACE TO LAY DOWN.....ASAP... thats my control , if I get warning signals.....not always that lucky, but usually am.

It means I will be able to drive again! Therefore leading me to more stable employment! Bring it on! I've not siezed since Dec!
To keep our 11 month son from having to be entubated because of his seizures and spending more than a week in NICU
It means being controlled without the side effects of medication. I haven't seized since 2009.

No alcohol, can't stay up past 10, low stress exercise, eating really healthy, no mental stress, no concerts, great meds. Which is really hard since I'm only 19 and was diagnosed 2 months ago and had 5 seizures since, I just want to drive again!! Ugh
A guarantee would be nice but not going to happen, but for now I would settle for feeling alive once again and not zombie like
Being controlled without side effects of meds is correct. Not having a seizure is Awesome, but not having a life sucks.
red meat no more than once a week, 1000mg extended release depakote at night, minimum of 7 hours of sleep
NO MORE SEIZURES WHILE ON MEDS!!
Few seizures and still know you are alive!
To be ready for anything, to look at things logicly and not get to happy or to sad...to be neutral and never at any extreme point of the spectrum
not being under stress. It has almost been 6 months since I have had one.
I've had seizures for 13 years now and last week I was diagnosed with Lupus. Possibly that's why I've been having seizures all these years.
seizure control to me means getting thru the day without too many simple partials.
Our child has intractable epilepsy. For him, control means only one seizure per day. We'll take that!
Being seizure free

from_name: Dr. Raj Bhayani, Specialist Doctor of Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT)
message: I love seeing the comments on links like this because it allows me to ask more probing questions to my patients. This allows me to help them more and gives them more control over their symptoms/seizures. Thank you all for sharing!
I don't want to see my son have ANY sort, any type of seizure-that's my where definition of control is-but sometimes it's not that easy!

I have had some control for 3 years when I found out the stress att my place of employment was causing them and putting a strain on my marriage could not figure it out at the beginning but when I got laid off and started getting enough sleep and not being stressed that's when I noticed and now its been 3 years seizure free and I haven't had any medication

I am so glad to see physicians reading this thread!  Seizure control really is different for each and every one of us.  I never dreamed I could reach seizure freedom, but am 3 years seizure free for the first time in 46 years - but I know that they can come back at any moment if I don't do the right things (take my meds regularly, get enough sleep, be careful with my stress levels...)
they tell me seizure control is taking my meds, dont get stressed, get enough sleep , being a mom thats impossible, i have no idea when theyre comming so i dont know what seizure control is

This page is for friends of Epilepsy Advocate to discuss their concerns and share support and encouragement for each other. Please make sure your posts align with the philosophy of our page. If you are unsure about what you can post, check out our community guidelines. Thanks.
There are only a few photos, are u going to post them all?

I always do that...even when I have my woman well checks I take my husband with me, he wouldn't have it any other way....he's afraid the stress will cause me to go into a siezure. The nurse always ask me if I'm sure I want him to go back with me....I tell her yes and she gives me a look....lol
I always do this, it really helps me to recall later.

i have grand mal seizures and dont remember anything for at least 45 min after they happen.  i HAVE to bring someone in with me to be able to describe what happened before and after each seizure.  We are still trying to figure out my tirggers and such nd my lack of memeory REALLY get in the way of that

I think everyone should have a patient advocate, especially if there is any kind of memory loss involved. A patient can become overwhelmed with the emotional aspects of what a doctor is talking to them about and it becomes very difficult for them to then connect with what is being said on a medical level. A second "detached" person taking notes can be a lifesaver during the appointment and after!
My mom comes to my yearlie exams, and she remebers everything. I remeber most for a while. So having extra ears really helps!

I have got someone that's going with me to her appts, but not family...hopefully it'll all work out soon....her next appt is the 17th of next month and wished it was a bit sooner though...so can't wait
I have grand mals n lately up to an hours worth:-(  so I can't remember anything for long periods of time so I'm glad that I have friend's that r there to help me out n remind me when I forget:-)

Do you sometimes forget whether or not you have taken your medication?? ~~withOUT the medicine I have at least 5 Grand-Mals (with posticle paralysis/loss of voice) and countless Petite-Mals & others....so I'm afraid NOT to take it...ended up in the hospital with toxic shock/potassium so low I could've had a heart attack ...so after several trys I came up with a way to remember: IN THE PM I TURN THE BOTTLE UPSIDE DOWN AFTER I TAKE IT ...SO IF IT IS RIGHT SIDE UP WHEN I'M WONDERING IN AN HOUR I'LL KNOW I DIDN'T TAKE IT...IN THE MORNING I LEAVE IT UPRIGHT (never had trouble remembering in the morning)~~hopes this helps someone =))
We count on our familes and friends during seizures and believe it or not, our doctors also count on what these people know during our appointments.

My four words:  Epilepsy, you are fired!
That's MY Dad!
Start at my sons middle school where I've had to educate most if not all of his teachers on epilepsy.

I explain how scary it is waking up from a seizure, how I had a miracle moment when I survived a ten minute grand mal with no brain damage, explain how misunderstood the condition is, tell people I got it from a slight head injury when I was a kid, and how it can be hereditary. Then I explain all the many types and signs of epilepsy. People are always very surprised.

I raise awareness of Epilepsy by posting on Facebook and also on
The Epilepsy Foundtation's "A Storm within" ~Jessica, come and join
the discussion on "The Storm Within"~we want to raise awareness
of Epilepsy to the whole country!!!!

I raise awareness be because I tell people you can lead a full life despite having Epilepsy. People come to me in my job and say the are disable and can't work.I tell them I my story and I work travel 2 hour to and from work on public transportation and still has a life with my family.

That phrase, "Epilepsy is NOT me!" hit home,  along time ago, my friend wanted to give me the nickname "Sy" because those are the first 2 letters of my name, but since all people seemed to notice of me was my epilep "sy" ...I made her change the nick name to "Seymour" because I believe I am/ WE are so much MORE than this thing!!!
I'm a person just like you or anyone else. However I don't let epilepsy set my boundaries. I always push beyond what others tell I can not do.

@ Lisa> pretty much it is when your brain miss fires... causes a seizure...I have partial  onset... I suffer from SEVERE migraines...just about everyday of my life!!
@ lisa it's usually some sort of head trauma/injury or infection or it can be hereditary

I have 6 types of seizures and am on 3 types of medications. My seizures are still not under control. We have tried the entire spectrum of seizure medications.  I am not a candidate for surgery. Is there anyone out there to offer any support or coping stratagies?
Hi Candy-Actually, there are plenty of epilepsy resources available on Epilepsy Advocate’s website at http://www.epilepsyadvocate.com/resources/epilepsy-programs.aspx. Have a look.

Hey there, wondering why your comment was removed? As you may know, epilepsy is a complicated condition. That's why we are working hard to get the information out there. We appreciate your comment but try to keep in mind that only a healthcare professional can give proper medical advice to someone with epilepsy

Candy, I'm very sorry to hear that! I'm an epilepsy Advocate, and I talk to people all over the world who a wide range of issues, including your situation. Coping with epilepsy and patients like me are great sites that offer help, advice, and support. I belong to them too. It helped me with my decision for brain surgery and coping with epilepsy, and I felt less alone. My friends and family dont have it, and don't fully understand, but they listen and offer support. Instead talking to people with epilepsy has helped me accept, cope, and deal with the struggles of everyday life we live. Good Luck and Take Care! :)

I am an epilepsy advocate for Dover, DE.  As an advocate it is still difficult getting the word out about epilepsy awareness.  I have been to schools, small businesses. Health care fields.  But, it is not enough. Tried cup cakes no bakeries locally in the area. The 5th day program didn't go over well with district office of our local school district.  Can't do it in each individual classrooms, said there is to many 5th grade classrooms.  Any suggestions?
these are staggering statistics.We need more awarness.you guys are great.I loved this months issue packed full of great info.
no wonder we epileptics have a hard time finding a job. besides the fact thay employers just dont want to be bothered with us.
Right there with you Timothy....

My 10 year old is in a school district that does not have many cases.  She has several Petit Mals a day.  Her first Grand Mal went into a 45 min Status.  It's taken be 2.5 years but we are making progress in awareness.  She finally has the educational help, we are working on transportation.  The truth is in education.  People don't know what to do.  I am her advocate utill she is able to be an advocate for herself.  Don't assume all is being done for your child...You have to continuously follow up.......Peace

My 13 year old Has goten the vns implant for her seizures an the have stoped for now me an the doctors had it put in Her back in 2003  she was having 10&40  seizures a day she has now been seizures free for three years

I have epilepsy n March 26th is my bday. I plan on making shirts n having some type of coffee get together to talk about epilepsy m spread awareness.

We are having a "purple party" We are inviting all our friends and family, Purple attire is required, we are servivg purple treats, purple pinata to smash seizures, epilepsy awareness bracelets for everyone, prizes for the best purple spirit.  This is in honor of our son who has epilpesy, and a way to thank the community that has helped and supported us.  Last year we had about 50 people and had a great time, this year we will probably have close to 80 people.
Us too!! A purple day open house dinner party!! Also like we did in November my kids and I wi be streaking our hair purple!! (my son has epilepsy)
I'll be wearing my purple sweatshirt for Epilepsy Awareness month during the month of March for my Grandson !!
I am trying a fundraiser this year....I am selling bracelets with 100% proceeds going to our local epilepsy research organization. I think as of tonight I just sold the first batch of 50!

@Dana M Chally-Green: My family made our own. We used purple grossgrain ribbon, made the ribbon loop out of it and hot glued it to hold in place, using different colors of fabric paints, we  wrote/painted "EPILEPSY" on them, then put a tiny brass safety pin on back. They looked and worked great, and the kids were proud of their own special ribbons. :-)

On march 26th I am leaving for the National Institute of Health (NIH) in Bethesda, Maryland for my 3rd round of testing before having a Temporal Lobectomy to help get rid of my epilepsy which I have had for 35 yrs.  I am looking forward to it.
I hope to get a purple ribbon tattoo done in honor of my son who has epilepsy

I have a friend who very stubbornly resists it, I don't understand, any guesses?

They don't cost anything. But there is a waiting list that goes based not on When you applied but how quickly Who needs one first. You can Google  'Canine Assistance/Assistants' and itll pull their site up. They also have a FB page with all the proper links and steps you must go through in order to have one of these dogs. Even the vet bills are covered, as the animals are considered a service. My five year old son has sleep seizures, abscence seizures and more recently has had his first physical seizures. I came across this info while reading in the neurologist's lobby, while waiting for an apt. As my son stops breathing a few seconds into his physical seizures, this is something Ive taken a great interest in. Its a bit of a process, but they map it all out for you there. Ill try to find a link for you.

To their online homepage...  
  http://www.canineassistants.org/
And this one should be to their FB page...
http://www.facebook.com/CanineAssistants?ref=nf

I have epilepsy too! I started having them at age 15, and I'm 34.  It's been a struggle, especially when I started having 5-6 seizures per day, tried 7 different med's, and nothing worked. I've always been heavily medicated in order to control seizures, but since I had a Left temporal Lobectomy surgery 3 yrs ago, I've been a lot better, and on the least amount of medication for the first time!

I have had Epilepsy for the past 5 yrs, and have only been seizure free for the past 2 months. My meds will be gone within the next 15 days, so I don't know what I face, besides the ER. I have been doing what I have to do as far as trying to acquire more, without sounding like a whiny person. But yes, more awareness is definitely needed. I feel as though people think I am just making excuses when I try to explain the in's and out's of the probs associated with this illness.

I am facing exactly what all you guys are.  I am having major troubles with finding the right medication for me so like many I have tried so many different medications.  I also just had a left temporal lobectomy and that seemed to work for about a month and half  but then my seizures came back ...full force.  So i am back on many pills and we are trying to calm my seizures down.  There might be another surgery coming up but who knows until the new year begins.  I wish so many more people knew about epilepsy.  I am so happy that there are many people getting it known.  Together i know we can make things happen!

As you may know, epilepsy is a complicated condition. That’s why we are working hard to get the information out there. We appreciate your comment and try to keep in mind that anyone with epilepsy should consult their doctor before making any lifestyle changes.

I was diagnosed at 4 years old.. when I was 18 I went into an 'epileptic coma' for a week.. when I woke up, seizure free... until about 6 months ago.. I am now 30 years old... and after going so long without a seizure, i have to say ... This blows.
I was diagnosed when I was born,but I didn't have a seizure until I was 15, when my father was killed. It was then that I found out by a Neurologist, that I had petit,and grand mal seizures

I had my first seizure 4 years ago & still to this day will never know why!  I've had EEG & sleep tests & been to 4 doctors & on 5 differant meds, after all that I found the best Neurologist & the right meds & have been seizure free for 1 yr.!

I was told I had Epilespy in 2009;it was the first seizure I had every had at the age of 63, I must say God has watch over and protected me In February of 2010 I drove to school perfectly parked my car went to my classroom and a couple of my co-worker realized something was not quite right took me to the school nurse I woke up in the hospital emergency room. Glory to God I have not had one since. I might have it, but it does not have me. I would really like to know where or how to get the purple ribbon.

Hi Patricia. We are glad to hear you want to spread the word about epilepsy by sharing the ribbon! If you go to our Photos page and select the Profile Pictures album, you can click on any image you wish to and then click “Share” to post on your own wall or to share with your friends. You can also right-click the image to save it and use as your own profile picture, email it to friends, or share any other way you can think of! Way to be an advocate!

This page is for friends of Epilepsy Advocate to discuss their concerns and share support and encouragement for each other. Please make sure your posts align with the philosophy of our page. If you are unsure about what you can post, check out our community guidelines. Thanks.

As you may know, epilepsy is a complicated condition. That’s why we are working hard to get the information out there. We appreciate your comment and try to keep in mind that anyone with epilepsy should consult their doctor before making any lifestyle changes.
purple never looked so good, keep people aware!
Wow. What a great tool!
That's great!!! Let's people know we are not "freaks"!!!  Just normal people like them but with a disability.
Yes, were just normal like everyone else.  Some of us have never experiened a normal life so our lives with seizures seems normal because we have never experienced a life without them.
Thank you for putting it that way, Carol-that's probably the best explanation I've heard :)
